speechtext: In view of the importance of this Bill, I think we should have some explanations of its nature at this stage.

maintopic: MARKING AND INSPECTION OF FRUIT PACKAGES.
speechtext:
I may say that this Bill, to a large extent, follows the lines of the Bill which was introduced into this House last session. It is introduced on the present occasion in consequence of the complaints that have been made in regard to the contents of closed packages of fruit put upon the markets of Canada and of Great Britain by Canadian fruit dealers. Difficulties have arisen to such an extent as in some measure to have discredited Canadian fruit in the markets of the world, as well as in our home market. Serious complaints have been made by the purchasers of Canadian fruits. The Bill which was introduced last session aimed at establishing grades of fruit, and at placing marks upon the packages that would indicate the quality of the fruit contained therein. This Bill provides a machinery by which packages so marked would be subject to inspection, and for penalties which would be a deterrent to those who are engaged in the fruit packing business in case they wished to pack fruit in a way contrary to the marks placed upon the package. The Bill has been somewhat modified since last session, inasmuch as it is proposed to apply it to the domestic as well as the export trade. It also provides in one section to apply to all packages of fruit which are closed, in this respect not being limited to apples and

pears, as was the Bill of last session. These changes have been introduced because of representations made from various sources in the country, especially from the fruit shippers and fruit growers' associations of the various provinces, the Bill being modelled to a large extent upon suggestions made by these interests. An attempt is made in the Bill to harmonize the somewhat divergent views of the different interests, while at the same time interfering as little as possible with the trade so far as consistent with safeguarding the public interests. I do not care to go into the details of the Bill just now, that I think could be better done in committee; therefore, I leave it with this short explanation, which I think will be sufficient to justify the introduction of a measure of this kind.

maintopic: MARKING AND INSPECTION OF FRUIT PACKAGES.

speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I have no doubt that the tenderers know ail about these matters. I have no doubt that after they put their tenders in, they have communicated to each other, as I am told they usually do, what their tenders are. Now, Sir, a job may be on foot, and if the people know the facts of the case a job can be prevented from being carried out. I am not speaking of a job implicating the minister, but a job in which the tenderers drop out one after another in order to get a higher price for the building of the ship. There is too much secrecy. My opinion with regard to public tenders is that the whole public should know all about them right from the start. What is the object of secrecy ? The government will not tell us what binder twine costs ; they will not tell us anything. What is the object of hiding the facts ? The true way is to give the utmost publicity to all these matters. Let everything be done in the open, and then everybody will know exactly how the matter stands, and we shall have lower tenders, less jobbery, and no deals. The minister tells us that he will not give the information now, because if he does he is afraid it will assist in the carrying out of these deals against the government. But the fact that the people have full information in regard to these matters will prevent deals, if anything can be done in that direction. Therefore, we are entitled to have this motion passed, and to have the minister give full information to parliament. The plan that has been pursued in the past must stop-that of the government, on their own sweet will, without giving sufficient reasons, saying, We cannot bring down the papers about this or that. Parliament is entitled to receive full information on all these matters, and should not be satisfied without
having the fullest information in the papers asked for by the hon. member for Victoria, B.C.

As I understand it, the only thing that, in the opinion of the hon. minister, should be kept secret is the prices of the various competitors, in the event of his asking for further tenders. I would not wish to urge the government to divulge a matter of business which it would be in the public interest to keep private. Still, when that feature is considered, what is there in it ? These tenderers, whoever they may be, have that information. Each one can give the amount of his tender to another ; they can impart that information to any one they please ; the minister cannot prevent them. That is the only reason advanced for withholding the papers. It seems to me, in listening to the discussion, that the interests of the department would be served by the amounts of these tenders being known, should the department have to resort to fresh tenders. There has been no argument at all to support the hon. minister in his determination to keep these papers back. As I understand it, he has these gentlemen in his hands, if they are responsible parties. One safeguard, however, seems to have been overlooked altogether in order to secure bona fide tenderers ; that is, the usual deposit has not been required. A very large amount of money is involved in the construction of these boats, and the ordinary course followed in all the departments is to require a deposit with each tender. That is done for the very purpose of preventing the withdrawing of tenders. The hon. gentleman says that one of the tenders which has been accepted has been withdrawn. But the tenderer cannot withdraw under the law, and, if he is responsible, it seems to me that it would be the duty of the department to hold him to his contract. The House being in session, and there being now an actual contract, it seems to me, unless some other reason is given, that the minister is unduly cautious in withholding the information asked for.

The hon. gentleman knows that there has never been a case in the history of the government when tenders have been communicated to the House before the contract has been entered into. There are six or eight of these tenderers, and if I published the names the lower one would withdraw altogether. In this case the lowest tender has been accepted, the contract has been made out, it will be executed in a short time, and the moment it is executed the information will be given to my hon. friend. There is no disposition to withhold the information ; but I could not undertake to advise the House to make a new departure and publish the tenders which have been received before the contract is entered into. The MINISTER OF FINANCE (Hon. W.
S.	Fielding). The question involved is one of principle, applying not to this particular department alone, but to all departments which invite public tenders. I have to dissent entirely from the principle laid down by the hon. member for Jacques Cartier (Mr. Monk) as to the right of parliament to control these documents in that broad and unqualified way that he states. He admits that ministers may withhold documents for reasons of state. If we accept that definition, the minister of this department says that for reasons of state he does not deem it proper to bring these papers down. No one disputes the authority of parliament; but the public business could not be carried on in the departments If the principle which the hon. gentleman has laid down were adopted. Take the Department of Railways, the Department of Public Works, or the Post Office Department, which make many contracts ; if, the moment a number of tenders were received, the list were pro-17
duced in the House of Commons, there would be an end to all competition. It is said that in this particular case the tenderers themselves have probably a knowledge of one another's tenders. That is only a matter of guess work ; they may or may not. But it is positive that if we bring the papers down, every one of them will have that information, and they will have an invitation to put their heads together and make a combination against the public interest. Those who are in the habit of inviting tenders know perfectly well that when you have a list of tenders before you, it is absolutely necessary, in the public interest, to treat that list as confidential until the contract has been signed, sealed and delivered. The adoption of any policy at variance with that would not be in the public interest, and no self-respecting government should allow such a policy to be adopted.

speechtext: If I remember rightly, in nearly every state of the union one of the conditions in the letting of contracts for public works is that the tenders shall be opened in public, and this condition is insisted on in the cities and municipalities in nearly every part of America. speechtext: Yes, but that does not make the principle laid down by the Minister of Finance the correct one. The time must arrive when, in order to assure the parties tendering that they shall have fair-play and to protect the interests of the public, a day will be fixed in every case for the reception and opening of tenders, and all tenders will be opened in public. Will the hon. gentleman pardon me ? I did not ask him whether he had ever opened the tenders, but I did ask him to tell this House how long he has entertained the opinion he has now expressed.

speechtext: I am coming to that particular question. I freely admit that the principle I advocate now, I did not practise when I was administering the affairs of the country, and I admit that the present government is simply following up the practice followed by us. But there is this difference to be taken into account. There is a stranger at present ruling on the throne of the Stuart, and therefore it is perhaps time now that a system, which might not have been used when we were in power, should now be changed and a different principle adopted. But I was simply answering the statement of the Minister of Finance, that all governments would have to follow the policy adopted by this one and that to adopt any other would put au end almost to constitutional government. 1 wanted simply to point out that in nearly every country in the world-I do not know about Great Britain, but in all the states of the union-the contractor, before he tenders, insists that the day of opening of tenders should be published and that he should be given the opportunity of being present when the tenders are opened. I think perhaps that a principle which might have been worked honestly in our time, when there was a fair and honest administration in office, would be opened to suspicion at present and another should be adopted.
I hope that the doctrine is not being laid down now by the Liberal party that a new and progressive principle should not be adopted.
A pernicious principle.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext:
It is a pernicious principle which the hon. gentleman is advocating, because it leads to log rolling. It is when the tenders are not made public that the people get the worst of it.
The principle of publishing the tenders is adopted, the hon. member for South Lanark (Hon. Mr. Haggart) says, in all municipal corporations. That system prevents log rolling, but if you keep the tenders dark, log rolling is bound to continue.

It seems to me that a deposit should have been insisted on as a guarantee that the party tendering is prepared to go on with the work, if his tender be accepted. Had that been done in this case, the successful tenderer would have been bound to carry out the contract. The hon. minister said that the lowest tenderers had dropped out.

There were two distinct tenders one for a small ship and the other for a large one. The lowest tenderer for the small skip dropped out. I cannot tell you why he dropped out, but the lowest tenderer for the large ship accepted the contract and it is about to be signed. When it is signed I will bring it down.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: It does not make any difference whether the tender was for a small ship or a large one. Had the party tendering been compelled to put up a deposit, he would not now back out. There is a strong suspicion that he may have consulted with others and have dropped out for reasons.

The question is not, as suggested by my hon, friend from South Lanark (Hon. Mr. Haggart) whether the system is right or wrong or susceptible of improvement. The question is whether or not those papers should be laid on the Table at this moment. No doubt all transactions of the government have to be communicated to parliament to whom the government is responsible, but my hon. friend knows very well, and so does my hon. friend from Jacques Cartier (Mr. Monk), that it is against all rules of constitutional government to bring down any papers before the transaction they relate to is completed. The reasons are obvious. There are private interests which might be placed in jeopardy if communicated to the public before hand, and the position taken by my hon. friend on my right is a proper one, namely, that as soon as the transaction is completed the papers will be brought down. But it stands to reason that, at this moment, when the government is engaged in a private transaction with private parties, the interest of those parties may be put in jeopardy if communicated to the public. The public interest is not the only thing to be considered ; the private interest involved must be considered also. Private parties having transactions with the government may fairly say : We do not want our business to go to the country at large ; we do not want the nation to be taken into our confidence. But, when the business is settled, the matter will be ready for the public. This is the rule which has been invariably followed in this House. I could cite instances without number in which that rule has been strictly adhered to.
speakername: The PRIME MINISTER (Itt. Hon. Sir Wilfrid Laurier).

speechtext: The reason I put this motion on the paper is that there is a very strong suspicion in British Columbia that the letting of these contracts has not been straight and square. This feeling exists, not only amongst the men in the firms that tendered, but amongst others who have been watching what has been going on. I was told by two, aye, by three, of the tenderers that the specifications for these two ships were the most extraordinary they had ever

had put into their hands. For one thing, 1 believe, though tenders were called for the steamers, yet no specification for engines was included. Then, again, no deposit was asked on any of the tenders, and that, in itself, was a very suspicious circumstance, according to our idea. These contracts must have involved about $100,000 for the two vessels
No.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: Very nearly. One was for about $75,000, and the other about $15,000. Anyhow, we know how these things go. There would be extras probably, if a friend of the government got the contract.
It happened that the successful tenderer was a very strong Conservative.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext:
And what do we find now ? That the successful tenderer has been let out scot free-there was no deposit, and he has been allowed to resign; and, no doubt, we shall see a friend of the government get the contract

*
At a higher price.

Yes, at a higher price. That is the worst feature of it-that the lowest tenderer, owing to the neglect of the department in not asking for a deposit, is allowed to throw up the contract, and the country will have to pay more for the steamer than if the business had been properly carried out. The hon. minister said he was willing to bring down the papers as soon as the contract was signed. He will have to call for new tenders, or give the contract to another, and two contracts will have to be signed-and we do not know how long it will be before this is done. As for the argument that, in former times, papers were not brought down under the circumstance now existing, I will read what Bourinot says :
Whilst members have every tacility afforded them to obtain all the information they require on matters of public concern, occasions may arise when the government will feel constrained to refuse certain papers on the ground that their production would be inconvenient or injurious to the public interest. A high authority writes on this point : ' Considerations of public policy, and a due regard to the interests of the state, occasionally demand that information sought for by members of the legislature should be withheld, at the discretion and upon the general responsibility of the ministers. This principle is systematically recognized in all parliamentary transactions ; were it otherwise it would be impossible to carry on the government with safety and honour.' Consequently, there are frequent cases in which the ministers refuse information, especially at some delicate stage of an investigation or negotiation.

Oh, oh.
Hon. Mr. PRIOR, It seems to amuse hon. gentlemen opposite, that I should have a 174
little assistance from a legal friend (Sir Charles Hibbert Tupper). Bourinot says further :
Mr. Mackenzie expressed his opinion that everything that referred to the giving out of contracts of a technical and public nature, everything except the moral and personal reasons why any persons had been passed over, should be laid before the House.
Now, I contend that there is no delicate situation in this case. There is no reason that I can see why the papers should not be brought down.
I think the hon. minister should give a reason why they asked for tenders without making a deposit necessary. That has been the principle heretofore, and it ought to be the principle now.
I have stated that I would explain when the papers were brought down.

subtopic: CANADA AND ITALY-IMPROVEMENT OF TRADE RELATIONS.
CANADA AND ITALY-IMPROVEMENT OF TRADE RELATIONS.
speechtext:
MONK (Jacques Cartier) moved for :
Copies of all correspondence between the Italian consul for Canada and the Prime Minister or the Minister of Trade and Commerce, respecting proposed improvement of the trade relations between Canada and Italy, and of all correspondence leading up to the placing of Canadian goods by Italy upon its general tariff.
He said: I believe that this correspondence, when it is brought down, will go a great way to show what is the attitude taken by the different countries of Europe with regard to ourselves since the preferential tariff has been put in force. On a previous occasion I urged in this House that the adoption of that tariff would place the countries of Europe in a situation of hostility and offence toward Canada, and would contribute greatly to the diminution of our commercial relations with those countries ; while, on the other hand, the adoption of a preferential tariff without any negotiations tending to give us a really preferred position upon the British market, would not give us that advantageous position in that market which we have a fair right, I think, to look forward to. Speaking particularly in regard to Italy, I may say, for the information of hon. members, that a movement has been on foot, in the province of Quebec at any rate, and in the city of Montreal, more particularly, for many years, to improve our commercial relations with that great country. The object of those who, in years past, have

laboured in that direction, has been to give us such commercial relations with Italy as would lead to a favoured interchange of goods between Italy and Canada. There are many products of ours which would find a market in Italy, and many of their products which we require. There is a great demand in Italy, and has been for years, for lumber. Though I find it impossible to get absolutely reliable statistics, because most of our business with Italy has been through French channels, and most of our shipping with Italy, been done through French ports, still there is no doubt, and statistics will show it, that we have in the past, through the ports of Bordeaux and Marseilles, carried on a commerce in lumber with Italy. We would find also in that country a very profitable market for much of the mineral wealth of this country. There is also a demand in Italy that would afford a profitable market for our Canadian pork. On the other hand, we take from Italy at the present moment, olives, olive oil, wines of different kinds, most of them coming through France, or many of them, Italian pastes, canned fish and other products of that country.
As I stated a moment ago, earnest efforts were made in the city of Montreal by men interested in that trade to establish favourable commercial relations with Italy. I might mention Mr. C. H. Cattelier, a well-known manufacturer of Montreal, au Italian, who laboured for a long time in that direction, and Mr. Cressy, advocate, and others. But we were under the disadvantage up to within a few years of having in Montreal no regular consular agent from Italy. There was a consul resident in Montreal, but he was an unpaid consul, and his situation was such that he took no part in that movement beyond a certain general interest, because it was impossible for him to deal with the government with that authority which belongs to a regular consular agent sent from a foreign government, and being to a certain extent in the diplomatic commercial service of that country. For four or five years back we have had in Canada a consul general from Italy, a gentleman thoroughly conversant with the commercial wants of that coutnry, and who, upon his arrival here, gave the subject his particular consideration, and applied himself in a special manner to the negotiation of commercial arrangements between Canada ahd that country, under the sanction, of course, of the British authorities. Now, Sir, I hold information, though not obtained from that gentleman, that in the prosecution of that object he had several interviews with the members of this government, and I believe correspondence with the Minister of Trade and Commerce (Sir Richard Cartwright) and with the Prime Minister (Sir Wilfrid Laurier) as well. I am under the impression, though I do not i

subtopic: CANADA AND ITALY-IMPROVEMENT OF TRADE RELATIONS.
speechtext:
feel justified in formulating any judgment until that correspondence is before us, that the correspondence will reveal the fact that the government of this country, instead of seizing this opportunity of improving our commercial relations with Italy, were deplorably remiss in giving the subject that attention which it is claimed by many it deserves. At any rate, there have been no successful negotiations, so far as I have been able to ascertain, to secure a conclusion of some arrangements which would increase our commerce with Italy, nothing whatever has been concluded, no arrangement has been arrived at. So far as I have been able to ascertain, our position in regard to that matter has been altered. We occupy now the same position that we did before under the commercial treaties that country had made with Great Britain. We were not upon what is called there the general tariff, we were upon a special tariff, according to which the duty upon such articles as we sent to Italy was far less than it is according to the general tariff. There arg two tariffs in Italy; there is the special tariff which is favourable to some countries, and there is the general tariff which is far higher, and which applies to all other countries. As I understand it, we are now upon the general tariff of that country, and consequently in a more unfavourable position than we were before.
As I said a moment ago, it is impossible to have accurate data as to what our commerce with Italy is at the present time. But I have ascertained that during last year, in spite of these unfavourable circumstances, our exports to Italy amounted in value to $260,45S, and our imports from that country during the past year were only $144,573 ; that is to say, there was a decrease, so far as these statistics are reliable, in our imports of $250,000. As I stated, the object of this motion is to procure this correspondence. Of course I will suspend judgment myself and ask the House to suspend judgment until we see it; but I think it is in the interest of the House and of the country that we should know whether these negotiations are going on, and what has been the result so far.

subtopic: CANADA AND ITALY-IMPROVEMENT OF TRADE RELATIONS.
speechtext:
I would call the attention of the hon. member to the fact that his motion not only calls for correspondence exchanged between the Italian consul and the Prime Minister and the Minister of Trade and Commerce, but it also calls for correspondence regarding the placing of Canada by Italy upon its general tariff. On that phase of the question there might be some correspondence of a diplomatic nature, and to procure it the hon. gentleman ought to move for an address instead of simply moving for an order of the House. I would call his attention to Bourinot upon the subject, who says that correspondence between the Dominion, British and foreign

governments is moved for by an address.
I do not know whether there is any correspondence with foreign governments in relation to this question, but as the motion calls for such correspondence, I think it is better to call for it by an address.

speechtext: I will change the terms of the motion in the sense indicated by Mr. Speaker, with the permission of the House.

subtopic: CANADA AND ITALY-IMPROVEMENT OF TRADE RELATIONS.
speechtext:
There can be no objection, of course, to the hon. gentleman's motion for an address passing, and such correspondence as we have in our possession which is not of a confidential character, we will certainly bring down. But, I desire to mention to him that at the express request of the gentleman to whom he referred, the Italian consul, a very large portion of this correspondence was regarded as informal and strictly confidential. That, we will not be able to bring down, as the hon. gentleman will no doubt understand. With respect to the question of trade with Italy, he is right in stating that it is probable that a considerable portion of that does not come from Italian ports, but through French ports, and possibly, to some extent from those of one or two other countries, and it may be, therefore, that our trade returns do not very accurately show the actual amount of our trade with that country. That, he will notice, would apply rather more particularly to the question of importations. There has been a great drop in the importations, and I think it is not unlikely that it will be found that a considerable part of that drop arose from the very circumstances to which he has alluded. On the other hand, the hon. gentleman is, perhaps, aware that while the importations diminished our exports to Italy considerably increased. Our exports rose, I think in very nearly the same proportion, certainly as large a proportion, though perhaps not to the same amount, that our imports appear to have diminished. However, I can just say to the hon. gentleman, that we are very desirous of extending our trade and commerce with the Mediterranean nations as well as with any other countries with which we are likely to be able to open trade relations. As I had the opportunity of pointing out last session, one of the really important objects that we hoped to attain by the display of Canadian products at Paris, was the calling of the attention of the Latin nations more particularly to the resources of Canada, and explaining to them how they might be utilized for profitable exchange. The hon. gentleman, I believe, is right, in stating, as regards a considerable number of articles, although, if my memory serves me, not as regards all, the Italian government did accord us some more favourable terms. Personally, I should be very glad indeed to discuss the question with the hon. gentleman
when the correspondence is brought down, but he will see that it is hardly expedient at this present moment, pending the production of such correspondence as we can lay on the Table, to proceed further with the discussion.
speakername: The MINISTER OF TRADE AND COMMERCE (Hon. Sir Richard Cartwright).

subtopic: CANADA AND ITALY-IMPROVEMENT OF TRADE RELATIONS.
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, of course, I would not ask for any confidential communications. I may say, to put myself right, and also in justification of the Italian consul, that I am in no way in communication with him. In fact, I have only met him once or twice, and upon inquiry in Montreal, before I made this motion I found that he had left for Italy. It is merely upon the rumours on the street that I have made this demand for this correspondence. The hon. Minister of Trade and Commerce will understand that we would like to see anything that is not confidential.	.

speechtext: Certainly.
speakername: The MINISTER OF TRADE AND COMMERCE.

subtopic: CANADA AND ITALY-IMPROVEMENT OF TRADE RELATIONS.
speechtext: I would also take this occasion to ask the hon. Minister of Trade and Commerce, if it is true or not, that the government has been notified of this change to which I alluded; that is to say, of the change resulting in Canada being removed from the former list or special tariff of Italy, and being placed now upon the general or less favourable tariff.

subtopic: CANADA AND ITALY-IMPROVEMENT OF TRADE RELATIONS.
speechtext: I think the hon. gentleman is correct, but I will make a special inquiry.
speakername: The MINISTER OF TRADE AND COMMERCE.

subtopic: CANADA AND ITALY-IMPROVEMENT OF TRADE RELATIONS.
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, this debate, short as it is, has brought up one of the most important issues in this country, and the sooner the government of this country come to a new idea in regard to our tariff, the better will they be able to deal with questions of this kind. There is a new doctrine in Europe, and this is the doctrine of tariff for tariff, reciprocity for reciprocity. Every nation there is adopting that principle, and introducing it in the shape of having a maximum and a minimum tariff. By that they are enabled to maintain friendly relations with countries friendly to them, and by it they are in a position to retaliate on a nation that treats them unfavourably in regard to trade. Italy has such a tariff to-day; Russia has such a tariff to-day, and Russia is using it with great effect upon the United States. The sooner we in Canada come to recognize that principle, and have in our tariff maximum and minimum figures the better we will be able to deal with other nations. I go further. I was taxed on the floor of this House the other day by the Rt. Hon. Prime Minister (Sir Wilfrid Laurier) as to what my opinion might be in regard to preferential trade. I do not believe in onesided trade, even if it is with the mother land. The preference we have to-day is a preference not given to Great Britain, but

given to the manufacturers and workingmen of Great Britain at the expense of the manufacturers and workingmen here in Canada, I am against that out and out. I believe that the Conservative party, as a party, is against it out and out, and I believe the Canadian people are against it. The sooner we adopt this plan of a maximum and a minimum tariff, or, as I prefer to put it, of preference for preference, tariff for tariff, the sooner will we be able to extend our trade in different directions and upbuild this country. In connection with the old land, I believe that if proper representations were made to them, they will give a preference to us in consideration of the preference given by us to them, and the government made a great mistake the day they gave to the British manufacturers and the British workmen a preference in this market without getting one for ourselves. The opportunity is now coming in connection with the new Commonwealth of Australia, where they are adopting, as I believe they will adopt, the principle of protection, and a tariff for the encouragement of their own trade-the opportunity will present itself if the government is alive and up to date, to make some kind of a preferential arrangement with the Australian Commonwealth. The idea was brought out at the Toronto Board of Trade by a prominent merchant of that city, Mr. Hees, it was supported by the merchants of Toronto, and 1 believe, it will be supported by the people of this country. It is in line with what I have laid down already in my few remarks, tariff for tariff, preference for preference, and unless we frame our tariff in that way, and unless large powers are given to the Governor in Council to administer that tariff, we will not be able to hold our own with other countries. To-day the nations of Europe are being organized on that principle as against the United States, and they will be organized on that principle as against us. That is the coming principle, that is the rule that is demanded by the commerce of the different nations, and we must come to that in this country. I have believed in that principle ever since I have been taking any interest in our affairs, and the people of Canada are coming to that. The Conservative party has long ago come to that.

subtopic: CANADA AND ITALY-IMPROVEMENT OF TRADE RELATIONS.
speechtext: Why don't you abolish the preferential tariff ?
speakername: The MINISTER OP TRADE AND COMMERCE.

subtopic: CANADA AND ITALY-IMPROVEMENT OF TRADE RELATIONS.
speechtext: I am ready to abolish a preferential tariff to-day that is unfair to the Canadian manufacturer and the Canadian workman.

subtopic: CANADA AND ITALY-IMPROVEMENT OF TRADE RELATIONS.
speechtext: Why don't you do it ?
speakername: The MINISTER OP TRADE AND COMMERCE.

speechtext:
Why don't you vote against it in this parliament ?
Mr. MAC-LEAN.
speakername: The MINISTER OP FINANCE (Hon. W. S. Fielding).

subtopic: CANADA AND ITALY-IMPROVEMENT OF TRADE RELATIONS.
speechtext: I declare myself against it now. We will vote against it, and we will have it up in this House, and if the people are consulted, we will be sustained in it.

subtopic: CANADA AND ITALY-IMPROVEMENT OF TRADE RELATIONS.
speechtext: Oh, oh.

subtopic: CANADA AND ITALY-IMPROVEMENT OF TRADE RELATIONS.
speechtext: Hon. gentlemen claim great credit for what they have done in adopting that tariff, but they have done something not for the benefit of the empire. The way to do something- for the benefit of the empire is to do something for the empire as a whole. If we wish to support the empire as we did by sending our soldiers to South Africa, present the empire with a great warship as Cape Colony is doing today, and as Australia is proposing to do, but do not do something at the expense of the Canadian manufacturer and the Canadian workmen. Now, I would like to have an expression of opinion from the hon. Minister of Finance (Mr. Fielding), or rather the hon. Minister of Trade and Commerce (Sir Richard Cartwright) on this particular question, and let him tell us, to-day, if he wishes to build up our trade, whether he is prepared to adopt this new principle, a principle that is being recognized all over the world which will enable Canada to make headway, the principle of the maximum and minimum tariff, administering it on a line that will produce trade between two countries with benefit to both.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think that we may congratulate ourselves upon the fact, that, before a great while, we shall be able to ascertain what the opinion of the Conservative party upon the preferential tariff is. We on this side declared that we believed that was sound policy, and we asked the support of the people upon that ground, and were successful. We asked the Conservative party to say what their policy was upon the question. The hon. gentleman who at that time acted as the financial leader of the Conservative party, Mr. Geo. E. Foster-a gentleman who is not apparently dictating the financial policy of the Conservative party at the present time, but who was the recognized mouthpiece of the party upon financial questions at that time- Mr. Foster very carefully refrained from taking any such position as that taken by the hon. gentleman (Mr. Maclean) just now, and for which he. received the plaudits of his friends on that side of the House. These gentlemen opposite were very careful when they went before the country a few months ago, not to declare themselves as opposed to the principle of the preferential tariff. And, Sir, the success which the hon. gentlemen attained in only one province of this Dominion would not have been attained if they had declared the sentiment which they have declared in the House this afternoon. They succeeded in convincing perhaps the

majority of the people of Ontario that they were the truly loyal people, hut my hou. friend (Mr. Maclean) says to-day that that is not true, and that he is opposed to any preferences whatever being given to the manufacturer or the workingmen of Great Britain.

I would like the hon. gentleman to explain at whose expense he would give a preference. Are we going to take the tariff off the goods coming in to some other country ? We do not regulate the tariffs which protect manufacturers and workmen in other countries, and when we give a preference if it is to be at any one's expense, it is at the expense of the manufacturer and workingman of Canada. We go a little further and we say, that it is the policy of the Liberal party of Canada to reduce the duties and to remove to some extent the burdens of the excessive tariff which was imposed upon imported goods by the late Conservative government.
Mr. LaRIYIERE. Is that the opinion you expressed during the last election with regard to the tariff on agricultural implements in Manitoba ?

subtopic: CANADA AND ITALY-IMPROVEMENT OF TRADE RELATIONS.

I have not risen for the purpose of making a speech upon the general fiscal policy of the government, but for the purpose of calliug attention to the fact that my hon. friend (Mr. Maclean) has made a clear and distinct declaration of the attitude of the Conservative party upon the question of the preferential tariff ; that he apparently received the unanimous applause of his friends on that side of the House when he made that declaration, and that the people of Canada now know, what they perhaps never had any official statement of before, namely : that the Conservative party is opposed as a party to the preferential clause in our tariff.

in this House. He says he is glad to know that the Conservatives have now declared their policy. speechtext:
The Minister of the Interior says he justified the 20 per cent duty that the Conservatives imposed upon agricultural implements. He pledged himself that he would oppose it in parliament, but now he turns around without any justification and defends the 20 per cent duty that he previously attacked when it was the policy of the Conservatives. That is the miserable position that the Minister of the Interior (Hon. Mr. Sifton) places himself in to-day. He tells us also that his party has removed the burdens of the people. How

much have they removed the burdens of the people by their present tariff ? Not more than one-quarter of 1 per cent on the dollar, which makes it in round figures precisely the same duty so far as the burden of the people for each dollar is concerned, but it makes an increase of more than $1.30 per head on the population of Ontario, or largely more than $0,000,000 of burdens placed upon the people of all Canada. That is the policy the Minister of the Interior defends to-day. The Liberals for twenty years proclaimed themselves free traders, but the moment they came into power they increased the burdens of the people-if custom taxation is a burden on the people, and it Is-very largely. They increased it last year by $7,000,000 over previous years, and I suppose that the Minister of Finance will at an early day get up and glorify the great Liberal party because they have placed this further burden upon our people. The Minister of the Interior speaks about the members from western Canada. Well, I do not think he had very much to do with the members from western Canada outside his own province of Manitoba, and I would like to ask him what was the result in Manitoba ? The Minister of the Interior was elected by a large majority, but pretty nearly all his colleagues in the province of Manitoba were defeated. The whole resources of the empire were evidently centred upon the Minister of the Interior and he let his colleagues from that province go to the dogs. He did not care anything about them so long as he himself was elected. So far as his sneer at the province of Ontario is concerned, that we were only successful in one province, that is not true, because we were more successful than he was in his own province. We are proud of the record made by the Conservative party in the province of Ontario. We are proud of the members
