speechtext: I want to say a few words with regard to the Minister of the Interior. He said : We stood by our policy in Manitoba, and look at the result. Now, I remember very distinctly reading a report of his speech in Manitoba, and it was to the following effect : It is true, I was against the duty on agricultural implements ; I was a free trader in that respect ; but you must remember that I am only one of the members of the cabinet, and the rule there is that the will of the majority must prevail, and the minority fall in with it ; I still hold the same view, but since the majority of the cabinet decided that the other was the better policy, I had to fall in with it. And now the hon. gentleman takes credit to himself for having stood by that policy in Manitoba, when the reverse was the case. The whole tenor of his speech was that he could not get his own view to prevail and had to accept the view that was not acceptable to the people of Manitoba.
Motion agreed to.

Mr. JABEL ROBINSON (West Elgin! moved :
That inasmuch as almost every mile of railway in Canada has been aided, to a greater or lesser extent, by the Dominion government, the local legislatures and the numerous municipalities through which they run ; and large sums of money have been given, as well as charters, conferring upon these railways a valuable franchise.
That inasmuch as the railways of the country are continuously seeking legislation for the advancement of some particular interest, or for securing some speciiic object; which legislation occupies the time of this House at a considerable cost to the country.
That inasmuch as such legislation, in order to be effective for the purposes intended, should be well considered, both by evidence and personal inspection of the location affected, by the members of this House, to the end that the best interests of all parties concerned may be safeguarded.
That, in order that these ends may be satisfactorily attained, the different railway companies for many years past, have given free transportation to all the members of parliament;
And inasmuch as such free transportation, coming, as it does, from railway corporations, no doubt with a view of affording every facility to the members for obtaining the fullest information as to the needs and requirements, both of the railway corporations and the country, and, notwithstanding such free transportation is uniform to all the members of this House, the object and intention is largely misunderstood by the people, and construed into corrupt intentions on the pa_rt of the railway corporations, thereby subjecting both the rail-
529 FEBRUARY 27, 1901 530	
way corporations and the members of this House to an unjust and unfair criticism, which they are not always in a position to defend. Therefore, in the opinion of this House, the present system of free transportation is unwise and undesirable, and should be discontinued, and a system substituted which would be free from the charges of corrupt intention or from adverse criticism. That inasmuch as the railway corporations receive more than adequate compensation for that service as now rendered, this House is of the opinion that an Act should be placed on the statute-book making it incumbent on all railway corporations receiving a franchise or government aid, either in money or lands, to furnish free transportation to all members of this House, upon the certificate of the Clerk of the House; and that no mileage indemnity be hereafter paid by the government to the members while in attendance upon their parliamentary duties. He said : Mr. Speaker, I hold in my hand the * Hansard ' of this House for May 2, 1895, and I find that on that day a number of the prominent members of this House who are present to-day expressed themselves upon the subject with which I am dealing, although not exactly on the same lines. My lion, friend from North York (Hon. Mr. Muloek) who is now Postmaster General, introduced a bill on the subject. On the same occasion the Hon. Sir Richard Cartwright also expressed himself upon it ; the hon. gentleman who is now Prime Minister, the Right Hon. Sir Wilfrid Laurier, also expressed himself on the question, as well as a number of other prominent members of the House. These gentlemen all admitted the correctness of the principle of the resolution which I have moved. All they required was to have it put into shape, and I have arrived here to put it into shape. 1 have no desire to prolong discussion, but simply wish to say that the railway companies have no reason to complain should this resolution pass. The people of this country have established a portfolio almost entirely in the interests of these companies. That department costs us, taking into account the minister's salary and the salaries of deputies and those of the clerks, about $20,000 per annum, expended in the interests of these railway companies, and we have a perfect right to ask that they should in return give us something towards the expenses of the members of this House coming to attend their public duty. I could refer to the debate on the 2nd May, 1895, for arguments in support of this resolution, advanced by gentlemen now holding office under the Crown. I believe that in that debate the Minister of Marine (then Mr. Davies), said that the Canadian Pacific Railway had received some $62,000,000 from this country, and the Grand Trunk Railway $25,000,000, and neither had paid one cent back. If we obliged these companies to carry members to and from this House once a year, that would not begin to pay the interest. It is about time that the railway companies should pay some-	thing to this country for the benefits they have received. The city of Toronto has an electric system which contributes to the corporation some $80,000 per annum. Mr. CLARKE. Nearly double that. Mr. ROBINSON (West Elgin). Well, I always like to keep within the mark. It is high time that the railway companies should be asked to do this small measure of justice, and thus relieve members from the criticism and the charge, that having railway passes in their pockets, they are bound to vote just as the railway companies ask them. I want to relieve hon. members from the suspicion of becoming tools of the railway companies by the acceptance of railway passes. I am satisfied that such a suspicion is absolutely without foundation, but none the less it rankles in the public mind, and ought to be removed. I was told here a few days ago by a gentleman who occupies a seat in the Senate, at one time a member of this House was refused a pass owing to the stand he took, that for several years the railway companies had refused to grant him a pass, simply because he opposed some legislation they desired, and there are members of this House who pay their railway fares simply because their constituents are somewhat jealous on this matter. It would be much better that we should come here with passes rightly given to us, and not receive any mileage indemnity. There are hon. gentlemen who come here on passes, and then are paid $200 or $300 mileage because they happen to live a long distance from the capital. That is not properly understood throughout this country, or these gentlemen would not be elected to the position of being able to receive that favour during more than one parliament. Mr. A. W. PUTTEE (Winnipeg). I heartily concur, Mr. Speaker, in the object of the hon. member for West Elgin (Mr. Robinson), in moving this resolution. I have noticed with some curiosity the different positions taken by some hon. members in the debate in this House in 1895, when a Bill was introduced dealing with this question, and that taken by them in 1898 when a Bill dealing with the same question was introduced by the former member for Yale and Cariboo (Mr. Bostock). I was some-j what surprised to find that many gentlemen, who spoke heartily on the first occasion in favour of the Bill, found reason on the second occasion to recant their former position, or else were absent from their seats. I must say, in my opinion, it hardly becomes the dignity of a member of this House to travel on favours granted by a railway company, especially when we consider that these companies must necessarily apply to parliament frequently for legislation in their interests. Undoubtedly a well-defined suspicion exists in the public mind i that the complimentary tickets which these

companies bestow, are no small factor In putting through legislation in their favour ; and that to this cause is attributable the very easy manner in which such legislation is frequently irat through. I do not for one moment question the sincerity of any hon. gentleman when he tells me that the acceptance of a pass makes no difference whatever in his attitude towards the railway companies in this House, but I do think that there is cause for the suspicion that, taking it in the aggregate, this House is rather more lenient and less circumspect in dealing with railway legislation than it would otherwise be.
It is hardly fair that we should draw mileage from the government and at the same time accept railway passes from the companies. I do not pretend to be supersensitive in the matter, but I must say that the two seem incompatible. I think it only right, in fact I think it imperative, that members elected to this House should have the opportunity of travelling free over all the railway lines in the country if they see fit. They should have every opportunity and facility to visit various parts of the country and the public works there constructed ; and should the hon. gentleman who has moved this resolution not have taken the proper method of reaching and attaining the object he has in view, I hope we will have a promise from the government that hereafter, in all Bills coming before us for the granting of favours to railway companies, a clause will be introduced compelling these companies to give members of the House of Commons the privilege of travelling free over their lines. That would meet the case exactly, but in the meantime, I propose to support the motion as it stands.
While I have seconded the motion in the absence of the hon. member for Vancouver (Mr. Smith), I wish to say that I do not quite agree with the resolution in its entirety.
Oh, oh.

If these hon. gentlemen who interrupt will have a little patience, I will explain my position. My view as regards the mileage allowance is that it is given, not only for the purpose of covering the cost of railway tickets, but the pullman fares and board while travelling, and also as an allowance for the time occupied in travel. I would have preferred had the resolution of the hon. gentleman simply been that the cost of the ticket be deducted from the mileage allowance, but inasmuch as he has not seen fit to make that provision, I am quite willing to second the resolution, and vote for it as it stands. Will those hon. gentlemen who laughed a while ago, smile now ?
Where is the joke ?

If the hon. gentleman is too obtuse to see it, I am afraid it would be useless for me to try and make it clear to him. You will recollect, Sir, that the former member for Yale and Cariboo (Mr. Bostock) introduced a Bill some two sessions ago for the purpose of regulating this very matter, and if my memory serves me correctly, a number of hon. members supported that Bill. I myself was in accord with its provisions, but I do not think I was present when the vote was taken, and because I was not present, I was accused in a western paper which supports the government of not being in favour of it. I may say that I myself have been frequently vilified because I accepted a pass from a railway company, and I feel strongly that this matter ought not to be left in its present position. The opportunity should not be allowed any one of accusing any hon. member of being favourable to a railway company because he accepts a pass from it, and for that reason, if no other, I would support this motion. But I believe further, that it is in the interests of the country that all members of parliament should be free to travel throughout the country and visit the various public' works, if they so desire, without having to pay their railway fares. They would then be able to inspect the public works themselves, and satisfy themselves as to the utility of these works, and the desirability of carrying them on. I am not one of those who think that hon. members are influenced in their conduct by the acceptance of a pass, and I do not think it should be left in the mouth of any one to question the motive of any hon. member who accepts a railway pass. For these reasons I propose to vote for the resolution of my hon. friend from West Elgin.

I recollect very well the discussion referred to by the hon. member for West Elgin (Mr. Robinson) this afternoon. In that discussion the present Prime Minister (Rt. Hon. Sir Wilfrid Laurier), the Minister of Trade and Commerce (Hon. Sir Richard Cartwright), the Postmaster General (Hon. Mr. Mulock), and, I believe, the Minister of Marine and Fisheries (Hon. Sir Louis Davies), all pledged themselves on the floor of this House to this extent, namely, that the practice of taking passes and mileage indemnity was an improper one, and one which put hon. members in a bad light before the public. And they all agreed that something should be done to remedy the evil. If these hon. gentlemen will look up the record, they will find that they pledged themselves to do something in this sense. It is a public scandal that members of parliament should accept passes from the railway companies, travel free, and then go into our accountant's office and draw mileage for expenses they never paid.
There is an agitation in this House to-day for an increase in the indemnity of mem-

bers of parliament, and one justification given for tlie taking of mileage by members who travel on railway passes, is that the sessional indemnity is not sufficient. I hope that a reform will take place, and declare myself in favour of an increased indemnity. But I am opposed to the taking of mileage, as we take it now, and the use of passes. These gentlemen who are responsible for the conduct of this House, and who have pledged themselves to effect a reform in this matter-the Prime Minister, the Minister of Trade and Commerce, and the Postmaster General-are bound to express their opinion on this resolution, and are bound by the promise they gave, to wipe out this scandal. The people do not like it, the public press have spoken against it, and the proper thing to do is either to make the railways carry members free or increase the indemnity, and give a larger mileage allowance. The mileage allowance now given is not simply intended to cover the travelling expenses of a member on the one trip to Ottawa and return. I know of three or four members to whom it costs as much as $300 and $400 a session in railway fares to and from their homes during the session, and it is needless to add that these hon. gentlemen pay their own fares. The thing as it stands to-day, is all wrong. It lowers the dignity of this House in the eyes of the people and ought to be abolished. As regards the question of railway fares, the railway companies should be obliged to carry the people's representatives free. There are countries where that is the law. In Prance, Italy and some other European countries, and in a good many states of the Union, that is the law. It is high time this scandal should be abolished. I am quite willing to vote for the resolution of my hon. friend from Elgin, and I do so mainly as a protest against the present condition of things. I say it here now, and have said it before in my own constituency, that I am in favour of an increase in the sessional indemnity to hon. members.

The question brought up by this resolution is not a new one. A couple of sessions ago it was brought before this House by the then member for Yale and Cariboo (Mr. Bostoek), and it provoked a discussion of several hours. On that occasion the former leader of the opposition (Sir Charles Tupper) took Mr. Bostoek to task for having brought up his resolution, and twitted him with being a young member, and like many other young members, a faddist-anxious to bring up something in order to satisfy his constituents he was doing something. I do not say that the hon. member for West Elgin (Mr. Robinson), is moved by any motive of that kind, because I have no doubt he could do something in his riding without having to come here and do it in the House. As no doubt the hon. gentleman belongs to the patrons or the grangers,
I presume he does not accept railway passes. No doubt, then, he would be able to get a pass and use it. We all know the fable of the fox who lost his tail. After suffering that loss he went around among the other foxes trying to persuade them that it was tlie proper thing for them to do without their tails also. There may possibly be some resemblance in this to the case of my hon. friend. I suppose this is a subject that should be treated somewhat seriously, but the first thing we should consider is whether this government or this House are in position to compel the railways to issue free passes to members. That is not decided, and 1 think it should be decided before action is taken in the matter. The question was discussed here two years ago for three or four hours, and I believe that other discussions of a similar kind have taken place in years gone by. It never seems to have occurred to those who brought up the subject that the government may not have power to compel railway companies to grant passes to members of parliament. If members of the House wish to accept these passes. I do not think there is any member of this parliament that would be influenced by the granting of such a pass. It is simply given as a matter of courtesy. I do not think such an imputation should be cast upon members as to say that it would influence any of them, one way or the other, in dealing with proposed legislation coming before the House. Before wasting time in discussing this question, I would like to understand what power the government has over railway companies in this matter. If they have no power at all, there is no reason why we should spend time in discussing it. In the meantime, if any hon. memBer wishes to accept a pass, that is a matter between himself and the railway corporation, and something as I understand it, that no other person has anything to do with.

It has been often said that bad company will have a certain effect upon men. My association with members of the House has not been so very long that, when riding on a free pass given to me as a member of the House, I have felt quite as comfortable as I should have felt if I held that pass as a matter of right. I have ridden more or less on railway passes given in connection with business, but I have always felt that I had given value to the railway from which I had received the pass. I do not have the same feeling when I ride on a pass under present circumstances. If there was some way to compel the railways to give a pass that we could accept as a matter of right I should feel more at home. If the government should think it best to make it incumbent- as the resolution says-upon railway companies to grant passes to members, that would accomplish what is desired in one

way. But I believe there is a better plan. If this proposal is gone on with I shall ask for an amendment under which it will be the duty of the government to furnish passes to all the members. Put the responsibility upon the government, removing it from the individuals members. In that ease, members who accept a pass will do so knowing that they have a right to it. There is a feeling in favour of an increased indemnity to members of this House. If that is granted, it should be made obligatory upon the members not to accept passes. Members who come here to attend to the business of the country have a right to feel that they are not under favour to a private corporation, and they also have a right to fair remuneration for their services as labourers here for the people. I do not vote for the resolution as it stands though I am in sympathy with the sentiment that dictates it. If the matter comes up, I shall, as I say, propose an amendment that the government shall furnish passes to members or that the members' indemnity shall be increased as recompense in lieu of the passes.

I think it might be desirable to have a word or two from the government with regard to this question. So far as concerns the argument that members of parliament who receive these passes are influenced by them, I, for one, do not attach any importance to it. I do not think that argument is of more weight that would be the argument that as the government issues passes on the Intercolonial Kailway, to members of parliament, therefore members of parliament are inclined to support the government. I do not think that has been the experience of hon. gentlemen on either side of the House. Still there has been more or less discussion throughout the country with regard to this question of railway passes. I am bound to say that I do not like the language of this resolution on the subject. I do not think that any member of parliament is influenced in the slightest degree by these passes, for I have seen members who, undoubtedly used passes given by railway companies, fight with the utmost possible persistence against legislation introduced by the railways that granted those passes. Nevertheless, we must have some regard for public opinion in matters of this kind. Now, the Intercolonial-we might as well begin with that-issues passes to members of parliament. I suppose it issues passes also to certain officials of the government. I am not quite clear, from looking at the Acts relating to the Intercolonial Railway, under what particular power the Minister of Railways has exercised that privilege. I am not speaking of the present Minister of Railways in that respect more than of his predecessors, for I believe that in this matter, he has only gone a step beyond the position of his predecessor.
Formerly the Intercolonial granted half-rate tickets or something of that kind-
To whom ?
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: To members of parliament.
No.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: I was under the impression that the hon. gentleman's predecessor had granted to members of parliament tickets entitling them to half-rates.
I think not. When I came into the department, the practice was to grant passes to members of parliament.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext:
Then, I am in error, and accept the hon. minister's correction so far as concerns the time at which the change was made. But I know that at one time certificates were issued entitling members to half-fare on the Intercolonial and, at some subsequent time, which, I thought, was under the administration of the present Minister of Railways and Canals that' was changed to the system of giving passes. I would like to suggest, in the first 'place, that it would be well to have the duties of the Minister of Railways and Canals with respect to that matter defined by an Act of parliament. I think it would be well to have the matter made certain, so that we should know, if we are to have these passes over the Intercolonial, just what our rights under the law are, and not have a matter of that kind dependent upon the practice of one administration or another. So far as passes on railway companies throughout the country are concerned, I think, perhaps, it would be a better thing if we did not have these passes, it would be better if some other system were provided. 1 have not considered the subject very much, but I suppose it could be accomplished by a prohibition to members of parliament against accepting these passes. I think, probably, it would be better to deal with it in that way than in the way suggested by the hon. gentleman (Mr. Robinson, Elgin) who brought the motion before the House. It seems to me that, perhaps, it would be more in the public interest that members of parliament, travelling on private railways, railways owned by corporations which have business before this House, should pay their fare in the ordinary way and that any saving of the cost of fares or anything of that kind should be dealt with openly and above board and in some other way than in the manner of receiving passes from the corporations. I do not know that I would have the sympathy of many gentlemen in the House with regard to that, I am giving my own individual opinion alone. I think it is possibly a matter which might well engage the attention of the right hon. leader of the govern-

ment and the Minister of Railways and Canals (Hon. Mr. Blair), as it certainly does engage the attention of the country, to some extent, from time to time. As I said before, l do not attach much importance to some of the reasons which have been urged against the present system yet it may be that the subject is one which could be better dealt with in the interest of the country by some other mode than by the system now prevailing.

I am sorry that I was not in the House when this subject was brought up by my hon. friend from West Elgin (Mr. Robinson). I understand that he has cited some opinions of my own in favour of the resolution he has just submitted to the House. I have looked up my words, as they are reported in the Hansard of 1895, and I do not find that I said anything very favourable to his contention. This is what I am reported to have said on that occasion :
This question has taken a wider range than I supposed at first sight it would, when the Bill was introduced by the hon. member for West York. For my part, I am bound to say that the Bill goes much further than I supposed, from a hasty glance at it. I had supposed the intention of my hon. friend was to prevent any member who travels on a pass from drawing mileage under the statute, which would seem natural enough. But the Bill goes much further than that, and forbids a practice which is now universal in this House, I may say. Well, this is a question of public interest, and may be discussed upon its merits, but if I may judge from the temper of - the House at this moment, the Bill is not likely to be discussed in that spirit.
I expressed no opinion upon the question which is now before the House. The question, as now proposed, involves a somewhat drastic measure, that is to say, that we should impose upon the railways of the country a service for which they had not bargained, and a service for which they should receive no compensation. It is true, as my hon. friend states in his resolution, and no one denies it, that the railways have received from the government, from all governments, from the nation at large, substantial subsidies ever since the beginning of railway history. But I would call the attention of the House to the fact that he proposes a new principle in British legislation, an addition to British legislation, in that, no matter what we have been doing previously, we should compel any corporation or any body in this country to give a service without compensation whatever. I think this is altogether against the traditions of British legislation. If there is anything sacred in British legislation, it is that ownership of any kind, property of any kind, is sacred, and should not be invaded, even in the public interest, without adequate compensation. In virtue of what principle would you impose upon the Canadian Pacific Railway or the Grand Trunk Railway, for instance, even though they had been heavily subsidized by the nation, the obligation of carrying persons or merchandise without compensating them therefor, saying to them : You shall carry certain members of the community free ? It seems to me unfair to impose such a burden upon any one, not only upon railways, but upon any individual in Canada. The argument that the railways have been heavily subsidized is of no force whatever. They have been subsidized for good and valid reasons at the time, they have been subsidized in order to enable them to carry on certain business, the business of conveying goods and passengers. It was not certainly contemplated at the time these subsidies were given to impose upon them any additional burden than those which were specified at the time. Therefore, for my part, I am not prepared to assent to the views contained in this motion. On the other hand, there is no doubt that there may be an evil in the system now prevailing of members of parliament accepting passes. I do not ask anybody to make a confession in this respect, but if a confession were required, I think there are very few members of this House who would not have to plead guilty to such a charge, if there be any guilt in it. Whether such a practice leads or could lead to the evils which are suggested, or asserted in the motion of my hon. friend, I am not prepared to say. I quite agree with my hon. friend the leader of the opposition, that it is not possible to say that any member of parliament has ever been influenced by passes, or that legislation has been affected thereby.
Moreover, if the motion of the hon. gentleman were to be accepted, the Act regulating the indemnity of members of parliament would have to be recast. My hon. friend suggests this himself, but this is not the way to do it. If it is necessary to change the Act regulating the indemnity, it should be recast on other lines than those suggested. The whole subject would have to be discussed de novo, rather than dealt with in this way. For these reasons I think that, though the subject is one which requires consideration, before parliament comes to a final conclusion, it is better not to proceed hastily, but to adjourn the debate to some future occasion when the matter may receive more careful consideration than it can at this moment. I, therefore, move that the debate be adjourned.
speakername: The PRIME MINISTER (Rt. Hon. Sir Wilfrid Laurier).

speechtext:
Before the motion is put I wish to make a few remarks, because this is a question which affects every member in the House of Commons. The First Minister tells us that the mover of this motion is proposing an unheard-of thing in proposing to put a burden upon the railways without any compensation. Sir, I contend that it

will Impose no burden upon the railways. We ask them to carry freight and passengers. Carrying freight may be a burden and require labour on the part of the railway company ; carrying a passenger from one point to another on a train imposes no burden upon the railway company.
What about his baggage ?

I am only speaking of carrying a passenger, not of carrying his baggage. I say that it is no burden upon the railway company, because the passenger walks on the train, and when he reaches the end of his journey, he walks off it, so that he imposes no labour on any railway official. More than that, as has been stated here to-day, these railways provide every member with a pass of their own accoi'd. They furnish that pass either from a proper or an improper motive. I propose that that pass be furnished from a proper motive, whatever may be the case to-day, and I am not going to inquire into that question. The First Minister tells us one of the things sacred in British legislation is to recognise vested rights. Well, I contend that we do not interfere, practically or theoretically, with any vested rights. Lawyers, especially, are apt to attach great importance to the question of vested rights, and to suppose that when they bring that up no further argument can be made. It is a question of vested rights, and therefore vested rights are as sacred as the British constitution. I do not place so much stress upon vested rights myself, when they interfere with the interests of the people. Yested rights in all cases have to disappear when the people's interests are paramount. You give a man the deed of 100 acres of land, he has the fee simple of it, his house is his castle, but, when you give a railway company a charter which will authorize it to go through his house, and deprive him of his vested rights in the house and the land, the house and the land have to disappear so far as that owner is concerned in the interest of the whole people. So, I say, that vested rights are not so sacred as these hon. gentlemen are apt to try to make us believe. Now, the right hon. First Minister says to-day, that we want more consideration, and that he would like to have this motion adjourned until some future occasion. This question was up in 1895, we have heard. No conclusion was reached then. I have a distinct recollection of the former hon. member for Yale and Cariboo (Mr. Bostock), last year getting up and proposing a resolution somewhat on the same lines providing for the abolition of passes and advocating it on the floor of the House. I remember another hon. member of this House, at that time, who is not a member to-day, getting up and leading the then hon. member for Yale and Cariboo, Mr. WALLACE.
out by the ear, taking him out by a back entrance, because it was a troublesome and embarrassing question for the government, and they wanted time for further consideration. Here, we have the old story repeated again. The arduous duties of the Prime Minister and his cabinet have prevented them from giving consideration to a question upon which they had fully made up their minds in 1895, and if they did not they have had ample time since then to come to a conclusion upon this subject. Yet, today, the Prime Minister proposes that they should have further time to consider the question. I object to all these postponements of the question. We have seen it from year to year. When a question comes up, and when the government are not prepared to come to a decision upon it they say:	We want more time for consideration, we will move the adjournment of the debate, and the debate is adjourned accordingly. I believe that parliament should be able to come to a conclusion upon those matters that have engaged its attention for years past, that have been discussed upon the public platforms of the country, and that have been before the people during all these years. For my part, although I do not like the wording of the resolution in its entirety, I intend to support it. Some of the clauses are all right, but some I object to, for instance, the one which says :
That Inasmuch as the railways of the country are continuously seeking legislation for the advancement of some particular interest, or for securing some specific object; which legislation occupies the time of this House at a considerable cost to the country.
Order, order.
What is the point of order ?
There are two hon. gentlemen standing up at the same time.
I say that while that clause is one that would not be an argument for the carrying out of the resolution, and that I object to the wording of it-
Order, order.
Railways come before the country for legislation, and they have to prove to the country
Oh, oh.
I have to congratulate the hon. member for West Elgin (Mr. Robinson) in having the most rapid promotion of any hon. minister in this House.
The wrong man in the right place.

I do not approve of the wording of that clause, but, while I object to it I do approve of the principle of the resolution, and, therefore, I shall vote for the resolution, if the House is to divide

upon the question, and to adopt tlie principle which I think is a correct one that its provisions should apply to all railway companies in Canada receiving a charter from the Dominion. As to receiving any subsidy or bonus, I do not care for that so much as receiving their charter. The charter of a railway company confers enormous rights and privileges upon the recipient. It is the duty of members of parliament to be able to go over the country, to travel over this Dominion, and to see what an immense domain and heritage we have. There is no burden placed on the railway companies, and 1 repeat that this Is not legislation, which, in my opinion, interferes with vested rights at all. The government railway, the Intercolonial Railway, sends passes to the members of parliament representing the people. That is the rule to-day. It is a very good rule, whether inaugurated by the present lion. .Minister of Railways and Cauals (Hon. Mr. Blair) or by his predecessor I do not care. It is a very good rule, and the other railway companies of the Dominion should provide members of parliament, while they are members, with passes. This would Impose no onerous conditions. The granting of a pass is no burden to the railway company, it imposes no onerous conditions, it does not call for any more labour on their part for a member of parliament to step on a train and go from one point to another. It does not impose any additional obligation upon the railway company, and does not add to the cost of running trains one cent. I therefore am in favour of this proposal of the hon. member for West Elgin (Mr. Robinson) and shall give it my support.
Mr. Speaker
Order.

I am in order; it is a motion to adjourn. I am sorry that the hon. member for North York (Mr. Mulock) is not in his place here to-day. As a member of the opposition of this House he introduced a Bill to regulate this scandal, if it is a scandal, but the moment the proposition comes up he is out of his place, and not here to defend his former record. The Rt. Hon. First Minister (Sir Wilfrid Laur-ier) has delivered, here, to-day, something of a defence of vested rights, but he has not had one word to say for the honour and reputation of this House. He places the vested rights of railway companies before the honour, and standing of this House in the country, and in that connection I wish to contrast his conduct with the conduct of the leader of the opposition (Mr. Borden, Halifax), who is not afraid to tell the House that he thinks the time has come for the abolition of the pass scandal. Are passes given for a consideration or not, and if they are given to members of parliament, are they given for a consideration or not ? I know what the rule is in the general manager's office. As soon as he finds a man antagonistic to the interests of his road who is in the enjoyment of a pass, he cuts off his head and calls in the pass.
No, no.
I know of a case where a black list is made for the general manager.
Name, name.
No, I am not going to give the names of people outside of this House.
Oh, no.

Oh, yes; hon. gentlemen do not like to listen to the truth. The general manager, in the course of the year, keeps a black list of the men outside of this House who have been against the interests of the company, and when the time for the renewal of passes comes round he consults the black list, and a new pass does not go out. The newspaper men of this country get passes, and a consideration is always implied. When the newspaper becomes hostile, the newspapers are put on the black list, and no passes are issued. That is a fact, and the people of this country think to-day, that some how the legislation that they do not like, and which is supposed to be against the interests of the people, has a connection with the free passes. If the hon. gentleman is up against a dilemma, now it comes back to my panacea, and what would cure it ? Government ownership of railways. That is the only thing that will let you out. The railway question will come up in this House every day; it will come up between the conscience of hon. gentlemen and their conduct in parliament. There is only one way to get around it; government ownership, and that will cure almost every evil we have in this country so far as railways are concerned.
Oh, oh.

These hon. gentlemen may laugh, but watch how rapidly public opinion is growing in this country. I am sorry the member for North York (Hon. Mr. Mulock) is not here now. I am sorry the First Minister expressed himself as he did, and I am sorry nothing has been said in regard to the question of members drawing their mileage while using passes over the railways. It is not right, and the public are against it. Gentlemen may say that the custom has been condoned in the past, but it is wrong and it must be stopped. The Minister of Trade and Commerce (Hon. Sir Richard Cartwright), a man for whom I have the highest respect, Is on record as saying some years ago, that this system is a scandal, and that something ought to be done to remove it. Nothing has been done yet, and as the member for West York (Mr. COMMON'S
Wallace) said, the question is being jollied along from session to session, and from parliament to parliament. Surely, the Prime Minister can to-day state that he will consider how to remove this scandal and cause it to disappear for ever. The right hon. gentleman told us that he would adjourn the debate, and that later on, when the House has had a chance to consider the case, there will be something done to abate the scandal. Well, I accept for the present the idea that the right hon. gentleman has thrown out.

As the hon. the mover of the motion (Mr. Robinson), is one of the representatives of Elgin, and as I am the other representative of that constituency, I take this opportunity of differing from my hon. friend (Mr. Robinson). I do not view the granting of passes as a scandal, and in proof of that, I may state that in the county I represent, that question was to some extent an issue in the various elections I have fought. I told my electors that I accepted passes on the different lines of railway, and that if elected I would again accept them. I have the happy satisfaction of knowing, Mr. Speaker, that my majority was increased on every succeeding occasion, and therefore, as far as the granting of passes is concerned, I do not really think that it amounts to very much. I understand that the object of giving ten cents a mile to members, for travelling expenses was, when the indemnity was '* first fixed, for the purpose of granting some consideration to those who lived long distances from the capital, and depriving those who resided in the capital of receiving mileage. A member residing in the capital can attend here at three o'clock in the afternoon, and he sacrifices no personal interest in the management of his business ' down town, while a member from Halifax. or Winnipeg, or British Columbia, must come here at the opening of parliament, remain here the whole time and neglect his private business. That is particularly the case with the British Columbia members. In my judgment, while it may be wrong to accept passes to some extent, the object seems to be, at the time the indemnity was framed, for the purpose of giving some indemnity at least to those who sacrifice their business in coming long distances. On account of the agitation in the press of this country, as to whether the! members shall have their indemnity increased or not, that has become a very public question, and before any change is made, It should be well thought out. I believe that those who live at certain distances from the capital should have their indemnity fixed at such a rate and no mileage added to it at all. A man residing in Ottawa should have his indemnity fixed at so and so, and the indemnity should be increased in proportion to the distance the
member lives from the capital. By that means we would to some extent indemnify the members who live at long distances for their loss of time, in neglecting their business, and on the other hand, those who live near the capital would be fairly indemnified also. To my mind, that is the only proper method of granting indemnity to members of parliament. Since I have been a member of this House-and I am here now for twelve sessions-I have listened to charges made against the Conservative government, and I have listened to charges made against the Liberal government as to certain scandals in their administration. Whether these charges were correct or not, I have heard them made repeatedly, but I have yet to hear one hon. gentleman in any parliament I have had the honour of sitting in, make a charge against any member of parliament, that owing to his having accepted a pass he voted on any particular occasion for or against a Bill. And when some gentlemen come into this House for the purpose of making a little cheap capital to promote their personal interests, I demand of them to bring proof of anything in the shape of a scandal caused by the acceptance of these passes. Why, Sir, I look upon it as an insult to every member of this House, when the charge is made that we are tools in the hands of any corporation. I have never yet been asked by any railway corporation to sacrifice my principles to support any Bill I did not wish to support. I have had perfect freedom, as I am sure every member of this House has had. I have always found, so far as I know, that railway companies, in promoting legislation in this House, endeavour to promote the legislation on the merits of the legislation itself, and if the merits of the legislation did not commend itself to me, and other hon. members, we were at perfect liberty to oppose it. So far as I am concerned, I am opposed to any change in the arrangements as we have had them for years. Until the government sees their way clear to say that they are not in favour of an increased indemnity, or that they are in favour of an increased indemnity, and that the way they' propose to increase it will be by the plan I have suggested, namely, to do away with the mileage entirely, and to have a sliding scale for the indemnity, paid to members of this House in. proportion to the distance they have to come to attend their parliamentary duties at Ottawa,
Motion agreed to, and debate adjourned.

(Translation) moved for :
Return showing the receipts and expenditure of the Montreal Turnpike Trust, and a copy of the annual statement furnished the bondholders of the said corporation by the Montreal Turnpike Trust for the past ten'years.
Mr. Speaker, this motion gives rise to a question which interests the city of Montreal and in a more particular manner the population in the neighbourhood of that great centre. This question, if I may say so, is one of paramount importance to the farming community throughout the island of Montreal aud the neighbouring counties. And I believe that if the government are willing to lend an attentive ear to the few suggestions which I intend to make in submitting this motion to the House, they will understand that it is in their power to remedy what I may call the deplorable state of things in connection with the roads on the island of Montreal.
I am happy to see that the right hon. prime minister (Sir Wilfrid Laurier) is in his seat, and I may tell him that should he consent to use in solving this question the great influence he is enjoying now
(Translation.) What is the remedy ?
speakername: The PRIME MINISTER (Rt. Hon. Sir Wilfrid Laurier).

speechtext: (Translation.) He will raise to his own memory a monument more lasting than brass in the hearts of the farmers of the island of Montreal.
(Translation.) What remedy do you suggest ?

(Translation.) I shall come to that by and by. As all the members of this House who are acquainted with the section of the country referred to are no doubt aware of the early legislation affecting the roads in the vicinity of Montreal, dates from a pretty remote period. I even believe that prior to 1840, laws were passed 18
with a view to the improvement and maintenance of the great thoroughfares running from the parishes in the neighbourhood of Montreal towards the city. At any rate, I find in a hand-bood which I have in my hands, a statute of 1840 to such effect.
Without wishing to enter, at any length, into the details of such legislation, it will answer my purpose to say that it aimed at facilitating to the rural population of the island of Montreal the access to that city, and enabling the people from the city to travel in carriages on roads kept in good repair.
But this legislation, which was never consolidated or improved as it should have been, did not participate of the character of more modern legislation. It lacks concision and clearness, and, what is more, it does not provide for state or municipal control, such as is to be found in more modern legislation.
Allow me, Sir, to say a few words as to the roads referred to here. There is the main road leading to Lachine, which runs along the St. Lawrence. There is another road connecting with the Lachine road and which crosses the hills, known under the names of Cote Ste. Catherine and Cote St. Luc.
There is the road to the westward of Montreal, running from St. Laurent to the River des Prairies.
There is also the Sault-au-Recollet road which runs from Montreal to the River des Prairies. We have also the Sault road by which the people from the counties of Laval, Terrebonne and the north reach Montreal.
There is another road leading in a northwesterly direction to the Victoria road, namely, COte St. Michel road, connecting with that great thoroughfare which runs along the St. Lawrence river and leads to Pointe aux Trembles. Those roads are under the control of the Turnpike Trust, an organization which is devoid of any municipal character. The trustees have absolute control over these roads, and have the rights of levying and collecting tolls. Owing to the increased traffic, and to the fact that the resources at the disposal of the trustees entrusted with the management of those roads were quite inadequate, the roads were left in a bad state.
From the statutes passed as early, as 1840 down to 1895, it appears that these trustees secured the power of issuing debentures and that they extensively used that power.
Without going into details, it is sufficient to my purpose to say that, up to 1890, the debt of the trust reached in the aggregate to over $200,000.
The trustees had kept paying interest on those debentures ; but in 1895 or about that time, realising that all hope of repaying those bonds and all hope of being able to raise an adequate sum to the redemption of those debentures was lost, they deemed it necessary to repudiate a portion of the debt



so as to be able to pay the interest oil tlie rest and, If necessary, to pay off tlie principal. New debentures were issued in virtue of an Act passed by tlie provincial legislature to tbe amount of $11)5,000. Those debentures are now in tbe bands of tbe Dominion government. But at tbe time when this new arrangement was made it was deemed advisable and lair to tbe holders of debentures to provide that they should be given some control over tlie management of tbe Turnpike Trust. It was enacted by tbe provincial legislature that every year or every second year there should be held an election of trustees, as tbe representatives of tbe holders of tbe newly issued debentures. Tbe Act provides that three representatives of tlie Montreal Turnpike Trust shall be elected to watch over tbe interests of their mandataries in tbe Turnpike Trust, so that to-day we have a kind of joint trust. It is composed of two trustees who directly represent tbe corporation entrusted with tlie management of the roads, and as tbe statutes passed from 1841 to 18(17 by tbe Quebec legislature and by tbe old legislature of United Canada stand, these trustees are appointed by the provincial government.
On tbe other band, in virtue of tbe above amendment and tbe readjustment of tbe debt of the Trust under statute 58 Vic., chap. 14, passed by the Quebec legislature in 1805, tlie bearers of debentures select, as their representatives, three shareholders whose duty it is to attend to tbe management of tlie roads and to watch over tlie interests of tbe holders of debentures.
Now, Sir, having explained bow this administration operates, 1 may be allowed to call your attention to this fact : that, as tlie various statutes governing this trust stand, tbe trustees are not called upon, as is the case with any other municipal or administrative body, to transmit annual returns to tlie authorities from whom they bold their appointment. We find to-day in our municipal administration in the province of Quebec, that every municipality is bound to transmit to tlie provincial government annual statements showing their management of municipal affairs, as also tlie financial standing of such municipality as is thus placed under the control of tbe provincial government.
In another sphere, the banks are called upon to furnish statements to the Dominion government ; and it is now-a-days the ad-knowledged policy of tbe law that corporations of every description should transmit such returns to the government, when they are invested with powers enabling them to manage a portion of the commonwealth.
Nothing of the kind exists in the case of the Turnpike Trust, There is nothing in the statutes which makes it binding upon them to furnish statements to the holders of debentures. It's quite true that a general provision under which the Turnpike Trust
may be called upon to send returns to the provincial government.

House resumed at eight o'clock. MANUFACTURE OF BINDER TWINE.
House resumed adjourned debate on the proposed motion of Mr. Blain :
That, in the opinion of this House it is expedient that all binder twine now held by the government, together with all twine that may hereafter be manufactured by them, shall be sold direct to the farmer at a price to cover the actual cost of raw material and manufacture only, with one cent per pound added, and that no twine manufactured or paid for out of the Dominion treasury shall be sold or disposed of in any ether way.

Mr. Speaker, this question of the binder twine industry is a matter of such importance that I feel that I would scarcely be doing my duty to my constituents were I not to offer a few remarks upon it on this occasion. In the province of Prince Edward Island the farmers use large numbers of self-binders, in order that they may gather in their harvests with despatch, and the cost of binder twine is a heavy tax upon them. Some years ago, when a duty was placed on binder twine, the farmers had a grievance, and when that duty was removed it was supposed that they would he benefited. The result, however, has been quite different. Instead of being benefited by a repeal of the duty tlie farmers of late years have been paying very much more for their binder twine than they were formerly called upon to pay. It may be said that the government is not responsible for this, that it was due to the war in the Philippine Islands, which caused an increase in the cost of the raw material. We know from the statement made by the hon. member for Peel (Mr. Blain) tbe other evening, that such a statemtnt is not warranted by the facts. Some small Increase has taken place in tlie cost of the raw material ; but as a matter of fact, there is no increase to warrant tlie high price which has been paid by tbe farmers for binder twine during the last four years.
This question was fully discussed during the last election in Frince Edward Island ; it was a burning question with us. The opposition held that the increase in the price of binder twine was due to tbe way in which tbe government bad managed the output of the penitentiary at Kingston, where the labour of the convicts was utilized in producing it-that the product was sold to favourites of the government at a slight advance on the cost of production, and then sold by these government favourites to

the farmers of the country at a very largely increased price. The hon. member for Teel the other afternoon entered so fully into this phase of the question that it is not necessary for me to discuss it now at great length. We find that in 1898 the government made a sale of 1,000,000 pounds or thereabouts of binder twine to friends of the government, Coll Bros., at $4,35 per 100 pounds. It had cost the people of Canada for its manufacture at the penitentiary $4.80, or a trifle over, or a loss on the transactions of that year of 41 cents per 100 pounds. In the same year binder twine was sold to the farmers of the country at 100 per cent advance on the price at which it was sold to these friends of the government. In 1897 the output of the penitentiary was sold to the Hobbs Hardware Co. for $4.04 per 100 pounds ; and that product cost the people of the country $4.84 per 100 pounds. It may be said that it is impossible for tire government to regulate the price of binder twine. There is one thing they can do- they can regulate the price of the article produced in the penitentiary ; that is certainly under the control of the government ; and if they supplied the farmers direct at cost, with one cent per pound added to pay expenses, as proposed in this resolution, they would give the farmers of this country binder twine for about eight cents per pound or thereabouts. Coming down to 1900, we find that the Hobbs Hardware Co. and John Connor purchased about $51,000 worth of biuder twine at an average of 7-i cents a pound. Last year it was said that a great change had taken place and that the government were going to sell direct to the farmers and give them the full benefit of the manufacture of this article in the penitentiary. We were met by our opponents with that statement on every platform ; yet we find that last year the farmers were supplied by the government with about $8,000 worth at 14 cents a pound, or double the price at which it was sold to friends of the government. I say that is an outrage. This statement was made here the other evening by the hon. member for East Grey (Mr. Sproule), and it was not contradicted. The right hon. First Minister said that on a future occasion it would be contradicted, but I say that it cannot be contradicted. Although it is perhaps impossible for the government to produce sufficient binder twine to supply all the farmers of Canda, yet they should sell that material to the farmers at the same price at which they sell it to their friends.
The hon. member for Peel says this is a small question. It is, so far as the amount of money involved is concerned ; but it is a matter of vital importance to the farmers of the country that they should get their binder twine at the cost of production. It was supposed when this government came into power that they would be benefactors of the farmers in every way. It was supposed that machinery would be placed 18*
on the free list, that has not been done. It was supposed that biuder twine would be sold to the farmers at the cost of production, but that has not been done. The government are evidently standing in with the combines ; they are supplying this material to the friends of the government, who are the agents of the combines, and as a result the farmers are paying 100 per cent more for their twine than they should pay under honest and fair administration.
My hon. friend from West Elgin (Mr. Robinson) made a proposition the other evening that an agent of the government should be appointed in each of the townships to sell the product of the penitentiary to the farmers at cost. It may bo impossible to carry that out ; but surely this business government can devise some scheme by which the product of the penitentiaries which is so vital to the interests of the farmers may be sold to them at cost and charges.
It is not my intention to take up any more time on this occasion ; but I see that the Solicitor General (Mr. Fitzpatrick) is in his place, and I would like him to contradict, if he can, the statement made the other day, that this product is supplied at 74 cents a pound to the friends of the government, while the farmers of the country are compelled to pay 14 cents a pound for it.

Mr. Speaker, I did not intend to discuss this question, and would not now, but that it seems to me the time has arrived when the government should take us into their confidence and say what position they intend to take on this question. I waited during the discussion the other evening to hear the government state their position, and I have waited to-nielit so far ; but we have heard nothing from them. This is a question which, while not the most important before the country, is yet of such importance that the members of the government ought to give us a definite statement as to the stand they propose to take upon it in the future. The farmer and all those who think about the matter regarded this question as one of the most important that came before them in the last campaign. I know that on every platform throughout my county, where almost every question was thoroughly threshed out, this was the one question, above all others, that attracted the most attention, and the one question in relation to which the government received the greatest condemnation by those composing the audience we addressed. I had opposed to me, not only a very astute gentleman, who met me on evpry platform, but, alone- with him, the late Speaker of the House, who. as every one who was in the last pari'ament knows, can place any matter in which he takes an interest before an audience in the most plausible form. However, when this question came up-and it came up at every meeting-he could not defend the action of

the government sufficiently well to raise any cry of assent from his followers ; on the other hand the people by their expressions, made clear their opinion that the government had been guilty of great wrong in the way they had handled the binder twine made in the Kingston penitentiary in the last four years. A government that had come into power with great professions of being a business government, ought to have managed an institution which required only good business ability in a manner that would have carried out, to some extent at least, the pledges they made to the people during the years preceding the year IStki. We ail know that if there was one thing for which the members of the government took credit, one ground upon which they appealed to the people, it was that, if returned to power, they would do all they could to crush the combine. We all know, that for twenty years, that was one of the principal cries of the hon. gentlemen when in opposition. I can well remember speeches made by leading Liberal members of this House, as well as speeches of their prominent supporters throughout the country, denouncing combines in the strongest terms. One would naturally expect that, when returned to power, they would take every opportunity to carry out their promises, not only on this point, but others as well. There were many of these promises made that everybody knew to be incapable of fulfilment. But this question of binder twine was one over which they had full control. Here was an opportunity to smash a combine, an opportunity to carry out at least one of the many pledges they had made. They had it in their power, in selling this binder twine, to regulate to a large extent the price at which this commodity was sold to tlie farmers. Some hon. gentlemen may say that the government control only one-tenth of the quantity used in Canada, and that by reducing the price of that small percentage, they could not keep down the price of the whole product. Any man who has been engaged in business will know very well that if one-teutli of a given product is placed upon the market in a judicious manner, it will have a tendency to bring down the price of the whole. If this five hundred tons that the government manufacture annually had been placed upon the market in a judicious manner, it would have influenced the price of all the twine sold to the farmers. But, instead of that, they sold it in such a manner-taking no precautions-that those who purchased it, were enabled to make a profit evidently of about one hundred per cent. We have the proof of that in the fact that the Brantford binder twine factory were enabled to pay a dividend of 100 per cent one year and of half that on an average for two other years, besides that the price at which the twine was sold each year was not more than half the average selling price throughout the Mr. SMITH (South Wentworth).
country. The government knowing, as they ought to have known, that they had it in their power to implement, even in a small degree, the pledges they had made, they ought to receive-as they did receive in the province of Ontario-the condemnation of the people for their management of the binder twine factory in Kingston. But the past is gone ; the future is before us. What action do the government intend to take in the future ? The motion of my hon. friend from Peel (Mr. Blain) is that the government should sell this twine to the farmers at an advance of one cent per pound on the cost. I am not one of those who believe in revolutionary measures or undue interference with trade. I think it is not the province of the government, under ordinary circumstances, to interfere to any great extent with trade. But, during the past four years, there has been an extraordinary occasion, an occasion when it was evident there was a strong combination amongst the twine manufacturers to raise the price of twine unduly. Here was the opportunity ; and it seems to me that it would have been proper for the government to have adopted what might be called even a revolutionary measure. I would not ask them to do that in the future, but I would ask them to place the twine on the market as any business corporation would, to sell it as the large manufacturers of twine would sell it, either direct to the farmers or to the retail merchants. And, in order to prevent the charging of extortinate prices to the farmers, let them make an agreement with the retail dealers that, if they sell it, it shall not be in excess of a certain price. The Brantford binder twine people claim that, though they have made these large profits, they have never sold the twine at more than 1 cent per pound advance on the cost. Whether that is true or not, I do not know. But, in any case, let the government sell the twine to the retail dealers or farmers at such an advance on the cost as will enable the government to have a small profit, say of 10 per cent. That would be a fair profit for any manufacturer, and I think that any manufacturer would be satisfied with it. I know that the government will say that they offered this twine to the farmers, and that the effort was not a success, that it cost the government a good deal to advertise, and that the farmers bought only a small quantity. Well, there are ways and there are ways. It is easy for a government or a corporation, if they wish to take a certain course, to put obstacles in the way of every course that might otherwise be adopted. The government ought to form its plans as a corporation would form theirs. Any corporation could find ways and means of placing this twine upon the market and getting :t in the hands of farmers and retail merchants without this high percentage of expense.

X notice in tlie first year the government offered it to the farmers it cost 50 per cent of what was sold to them for advertising the offer and the next year, last year, it cost 10 per cent of the total sale for the same item. There are ways that the government can easily find if they wish to place this twine in the hands of the farmers without an extraordinary cost for selling. It is not my duty nor the duty of any gentleman of the opposition to dictate to the government the method that they should follow in disposing of the twine, any business corporation can do it, and any business government ought to be able to do it. It seems to me that this article so commonly in use by. the farmers ought to be sold in such a way that they would not be pillaged, as I am bound to say they have been pillaged during the past four years through the binder twine combination in this country. I maintain that the electors were right in condemning the government for their course in this matter. The government had it in their power to prevent this combination, they had their hands -on the lever, and could have used that lever to prevent this condition of things arising. They did not do it, and they received the condemnation of the electors in Ontario for their course upon this subject, and I am bound to say this question had more to do with their defeat in that province than any other question.
Now, it may be said, I know it will be said, that the government did all that any government could do when they took the duty -off twine. It will be said, as it was said in the campaign preceding November 7, that the government took the duty off twine, and what more could they do ? Well, it is true they took the duty off twine, and I am obliged to condemn them for doing that, as I did all through the campaign. 1 maintain
and it was taken off to catch the farmers' votes. Now, what was the result ? While that duty was on, the twine we used was mostly manufactured in this country. We imported last year under the 10 per cent tariff, 3,301,000 pounds of twine. Even the ten per cent duty, small as it was, was sufficient to enable the manufacturers of twine in this country to live and to make most of the twine we used, giving employment to a large number of men and to a certain amount of capital. ment manufactures at its factory at Kingston. appeal to my mind that were addressed by the speaker from the other side, were those in which he condemned the government for taking off the duty on binder twine. With those words I sincerely agree. I think it was a mistake. I believe that the binder twine industry, like every other industry in this country, should be protected from undue competition from outside, and that it, like every other industry, should have the right to live in this country of ours. I believe that this industry, like every other, should be made to pay a duty on every pound of twine that comes into this country. I agree with our friends on the other side in that. Now, then, I approach the subject not as a politician, not with a desire to embarrass the government, not with a desire to contradict a truthful word that may have been spoken by hon. gentlemen opposite, but I approach it as a business proposition. We are manufacturing twine at the Kingston penitentiary, and how are we going to handle that product in such a way as to result in the greatest benefit to the consumers of binder twine, and at the same time to produce it at the least cost to the taxpayers of this country. The Trade and Navigation Returns show that last year there was entered for consumption in Ontario 3,900,000 pounds of binder twine, at 12 cents a pound ; in the province of Manitoba 3,400,000 pounds at 10 cents a pound, and in the whole Dominion there were 8,000,000 pounds of twine entered at 11 cents a pound. Let us deal with a proposition which represents an importation of 8,000,000 pounds of binder twine, or 4,000 tons. Now, according to the calculations of those familiar with the subject that 4,000 tons is about five-tenths of the total quantity consumed in Canada, or in other words, we import about half the actual quantity used. Eight million pounds of binder twine are imported from the United States, and that comes into direct competition with the twine that is manufactured in this country, which amounts to another 4.000 tons, including the product of the Kingston and Toronto prisons. Let us realize that the government manufacture of twine would represent

about 5 per cent of the total consumption. I appeal to any business man in this House if it is feasible, in view of this fact, that we could obtain the results which we are asked to achieve. I say tliat from the standpoint of a business man, who is going to invest his money in that business, that I would not put a dollar into an undertaking that could only control 5 per cent of the total consumption.
Then when we have solved this problem, the question presents itself : How are we going to sell this twine which we produce at Kingston. We have gone into the business for various reasons, but I shall not now deal with the history of our connection with it. The Minister of Justice (Hon. Mi-Mills) says that we went into the business for the purpose of giving these young prisoners who are not wicked by inheritance an opportunity to learn a trade whereby, in after life, they might make an honest livelihood. We can go to the Auditor General's Report or the report of the Minister of Justice, and take the items under the head of Kingston Penitentiary. I find that these figures were correctly stated by the hon. member for Peel, who, by the way, 1 must say, made not only a very excellent speech, hut a very carefully prepared speech, showing that he desired not to mislead the House or to misstate the case in any way. The hon. member for Peel stated that the government bousrht in 1899-1900. or the year preceding the 30th .Tune, 1900.140.335 pounds of manila hemp, at 54 cents per pound. 123,344 pounds of manila hemp at 54 cents, and 8,320 pounds at 9 cents. These were the only purchases made by the government during the whole twelve months preceding the 30tli June last, and this is the raw material out of which the twine was made that was offered to the farmers of this country at 14 cents per pound. The average price of these 272,000 pounds, or 136 tons, of raw material, was $5.60 per hundred pounds. We all know that there is not a pound of raw manila in a pound of twine ; at the most, there would not be more than 85 per cent of fibre in a pound even of pure manila twine. At that rate, the price of the raw material in a pound of twine would be 4-76 cents. To this, we will add the price of the cordage oil, which would not be more than 15 cents per hundred pounds of twine. In all, the cost of the raw material for a hundred pounds of manila twine would be $4.91. We are credibly informed by the Minister of Justice that this raw material can be converted into twine in the Kingston penitentiary at the rate of 75 cents per hundred pounds, or J cent per pound. This makes the total cost of binder twine in Kingston penitentiary $5.90 per 100 pounds, or. say 6 cents per pound. Yet, the hon. gentleman (Mr. Heyd), without giving us any data upon which to make the calculation, makes the assertion that it costs 8J cents per pound. I need not, and do not intend to prolong the debate by giving the average prices of the sisal, because that has not been brought very prominently into question. But, I do say that if the gov-

eminent offered to the farmers of this country the output of the Kingston penitentiary last year in quantities of less than one ton at 14 cents per pound, they were seeking to get too large a profit from the farmers, seeing that the cost to them was 6 cents per pound, the profit thus being over 12.1 per cent. Now, the hon. member for South Brant tells us, by way of excuse for the Brantford company, making such an enormous profit on the output of their factory, that they made that profit from the sale of raw material. But he does not tell us that they sold the raw material. He says had they sold the raw material without making it up they might have made a profit of $225,000. But there is an ' if ' in it, they probably could not find a purchaser. It may be that in the late part of the season, for a few days or a few weeks, the price of the raw material rose rapidly to a high figure, but we have no assurance that the Brantford people could have sold the large quantity of raw material which they had at that large price, and no assurance that they could have realized the $225,000 out of their raw material because they had no purchasers for it. His plan of making a sale of binder twine in the Kingston penitentiary is one, I am sure, which this House will condemn. He says it should be put up at auction and sold to the highest bidder. Now, that is just what we do not approve of. You can rest assured that if the Kingston penitentiary output of binder twine was put up at auction to be sold to the highest bidder, a very good price indeed would be realized for it. American buyers would come in, I have no doubt, and purchase the whole output at a high price, knowing by that means they would destroy all competition and be able to get a high price for every pound of twine required by the farmers of this country. What we want is to retain in our own hands the entire output of the Kingston penitentiafy, to keep it as a lever for the purpose of maintaining a level of prices. The hon. gentleman from 'South Brant (Mr. Heyd) says that 5 per cent is all that the Kingston penitentiary can turn out of the total requirements of Canada, and that 5 per cent of the total quantity would never control the price. But
I	think he destroys the whole force of his argument when he shows that the twine imported into this country last year cost
II	cents per pound. It appears from his statement that this 5 per cent, produced in this country, when put on the market by the government at 14 cents per pound, had the effect of enabling the American manufacturers of twine to raise their price up to 11 cents. I think that is clearly the case, and if the government, by inflating the price and holding back the twine from the farmers of this country, unless a very higli price was paid for it, had the effect of enabling the American manufacturers to sell the twine required by the people of

this country at an enormously increased price over its actual cost, 1 think that fact destroys the whole force of his argument. To my mind if we could judiciously manage the sale of this small quantity of twine, sell it only in small quantities, it would be quite sufficient to maintain a level of prices, and I know that was all that was expected by the late Sir John Thompson when the plant was installed in the Kingston penitentiary. It never was intended that the government should make money out of that twine business, that idea was entirely foreign to those who began this industry there. The sole intention was to use it for the purpose of preventing an undue inflation of price, and so long as we carefully guard the sale of this twine I believe that it is quite sufficient to maintain a control over the price of the entire requirements of the country. I repeat again, if putting the price of that twine at 14 cents a pound is sufficient to enable the American manufacturers to increase their price far beyond its value, on the other hand, retaining the control of the twine in our own hands and keeping it at a low price, will in the same manner affect favourably to the farmers the price of the remaining quantity of that twine which we are unable to produce in this country. I need not say that I should support the resolution of the hon. member for Peel. I think it is a motion in the right, direction, and I hope the government will accept the resolution and be guided by its terms. I pay no attention to what the hon. member for South Brant says when he contends that the increase of 1 cent to cover the cost of selling the twine is not at all sufficient. I fear the hon. gentleman is putting in a word for his own constituents who are large manufacturers of twine, and that, although he pretends to be a friend of the farmer, he is desirous of enabling his constituents to obtain as big a price for their output as they possibly can, notwithstanding that the farming community will suffer in consequence.

I was unfortunately absent when this debate originated the other night, but I have read carefully the speeches that were made, and the conclusion to which I have come is that there is a great deal of inaccurate information in reference to the binder twine industry, either on the opposition benches or in the Department of Justice.
