The member for Grey made a specific statement which I think it necessary at the outset of my remarks to contradict ; he made the statement that in 1000 the government sold binder twine to their own friends at 7i cents per pound, and that they sold it to the farmers at 14 cents a pound. The question as put to him directly by the Minister of Railways and Canals whether he intended to give to the House the information that they were selling the same twine at the

same time at these different figures. The answer he made was : 'Yes, at the same time and the same quality of twine.' Now that is a serious statement, an extremely serious statement to make, because it necessarily implies dishonesty on the part of the officers of the government charged with the administration of this industry. To that statement I wish to give an absolute, unqualified, positive denial. What the lion..gentleman no doubt meant to say, because I would be loath to insinuate for a moment that a gentleman occupying the position he does in this House would attempt deliberately to mislead the House and the country-what no doubt the hon. gentleman intended to say was that in the year 1899 the output of the Kingston penitentiary was sold to Hobbs Hardware Co. by public tender, and sold to them without competition for 7i cents a pound; and that that twine, so sold in 1899 by public tender was delivered to them in 1900, and the delivery took place in 1900 at the price stipulated and paid in 1899. Their basis of comparison fails absolutely. In one instance you have got the twine that was sold in 1899, as I said a moment ago, by public competition at 7-1 cents a pound, at a time when the raw material was sold at 5J cents a pound ; and on the other hand you have the twine that was sold at 14 cents a pound in 1900 at a time when raw material had actually gone from 5i cents a pound up to 10 cents a pound, at certain dates in that year. Now it seems to me that in discussing a matter of this sort, and especially in discussing it in the interest of that important element of the community which is called the farming class, the least that element has a right to expect is an honest and fair statement.
I will now proceed to deal with the motion, and in speaking of that motion, I would state immediately that we have no quarrel with a portion of it. With a portion of it we cannot have a quarrel, because, since August 1899, we have been doing what that motion says we ought to do. Since August 1899, it has been open to the farming class of this country, who apply to the Kingston penitentiary direct to get binder twine in lots to suit them from the penitentiary, and at what price V At the price of the raw material to which is added the cost of manufacture, and when the purchase is for less than ten pound lots, one cent a pound is added for profit. That has been the system since August 1899. It was in existence from August 1899, for the balance of that season, it was in existence throughout' the whole of the season 1900, and it is well known to hon. gentlemen opposite, those who were here during the course of last session, and those who took cognizance of it but who were not here, that the information was given publicly in this House that the twine was disposed of in this fashion. [DOT] I therefore say that we have no quarrel with that portion of my hon. friend's motion
which asks that the government should go that far, because it is merely giving effect to that which we have been doing since August 1899. But, when it goes farther than that, and asks us to pass a motion that we should dispose of binder twine to the farmer at a price to cover the actuffi cost of the raw material and manufacture with one cent per pound added, and goes on to say that-
No twine manufactured or paid for out of the Dominion treasury shall be sold or disposed of in any other way.	,
It is asking .us to do a tiling which, when my hon. friend comes to consider it, he will see is almost, I was going to say, absurd. Let us not deal with generalities, but with concrete facts. I said a moment ago, that we disposed of our binder twine to the farmer. What happened last year ? At the end of the season, the 1st of August, 1900, we had not disposed of more than half of the whole output for the year. We had half of the output still on hand. What are we going to do with that-keep it over until next year, when it will become practically valueless, and then dispose of it to the farmer, because, if this motion is adopted, we are not free to dispose of it in any other way '! This motion goes too far, as my hon. friend must see at a glance. It is all very fine to ask that we should dispose of this to the farmer, but, why is it that we cannot get the farmer to deal with us ?
speakername: The SOLICITOR GENERAL (Hon. Mr. Charles Fitzpatrick).

speechtext: You hay forked the farmer once ?

He was hay forked once no doubt. Probably my hon. friend (Mr. Maclean) knows when and under what circumstances. lie has no doubt a knowledge of the transaction. How is it that we cannot get the farmer to deal with us V We have offered this twine to him on the conditions specified by my hon. friend in his motion. Last year half of the output of the penitentiary was left on our hands. I think my hon. friend might go further; when he says that we shall be obliged to give all the twine to the farmer and no one else, he should adopt the other branch of the argument, and so be strictly logical, and say that so long as we have to dispose of the twine to the farmer, the farmer must deal with us, or that he shall find us a purchaser. I said that we disposed of this twine at the cost of the raw material, adding to it the cost of manufacture, and adding one cent a pound. Hon. gentlemen opposite undertook to tell us that the farming class were practically buncoed, to use an expression which I would borrow from the hon. member for East York (Mr. Maclean), by the government in connection with the sale of binder twine; that is to say that they paid much more for their twine than should have been legitimately asked of them. My hon. friend ought to bear in

miiul tlnit binder twine is a marketable commodity like any other. When yon pnt it on tlie market, the i>rice lias to be regulated by tlie law of supply and demand, and in order that the House may determine whether or not the farming community paid more for their twine than they ought to have paid, it is necessary to examine the prices at which others dealing in the same commodity in the same market disposed of their article. Let me point out how that applied. The government had no monopoly of this twine. They were competing in the market with others. What did we find ? We found this circular was issued at the time we were disposing of our twine to the farmers, issued by a concern that sells what they call the Plymouth Binder Twine. These gentlemen are dealing with the Kingston output :
In the hope of moving the accumulated stock of twine at Kingston penitentiary, the warden has again reduced prices, but thus far there has been no visible increase in their orders. With few exceptions, the farmers of Ontario, remembering past experiences, are apparently not willing to take chances with convict-made twine, or they do not consider the penitentiary article .as a bargain, no matter how low the price; otherwise, that twine should have been disposed of as rapidly as made, as the government's price has been, all season, from 1 to 2 cents per pjuud below the market quotations for twine of reputation.
That is what has tiikqu place, and that is evidence of those who are competing with us in the same market. It is that we are selling this twine from one to two cents j)er pound less than our competitors, and yet we are told that we tire endeavouring to impose on the farmers.
At what date was that ?

The date marked on it here in writing is August, 1900. My non. friends have reierred to tlie origin ol this industry at Kingston. They have told us that the intention was to start this industry for the purpose of regulating the price of binder twine in Canada. Bear in mind that the output of Kingston penitentiary is 5(j0 tons a year, and that the amount of binder twine used in Canada, is about 8,000 tons. We import over ten million pounds free of duty. How far are you going to regulate the price of binder twine with the amount we have at our disposal, it is impossible for me to see. But, we are also told that the intention of the government. when this binder twine factory was started in 1894, was that it should be used exclusively for that purpose, that it was not to be looked upon as a business industry to be dealt with on business principles. Let me draw the attention of m.v lion, friend to what took place in July. 1894, when this question was under discussion. At that time Mr. Davin asked that the government should pay the freiclit on the binder twine Mr. FITZPATRICK.
up to the North-west, and Sir John Thompson, then Minister of Justice, said :

I should very much like to be able to do so, but I am afraid I cannot make such a promise. Companies already engaged in the binding twine business are in the habit of paying the freight as far west as Owen Sound, but we would not be able, without involving loss and without calling on parliament to make good that Pss, to pay the freight on binding twine sent to the North-west Territories.	.
There is no suggestion there that this is to be dealt with on any other principle but a business principle.
I should like to ask if binding twine is being sold under ccst?

No, it is not. I mentioned the rates the other day, and I forget them fcr a moment, but binding twine is not being manufactured under ccst-the price covers the cost, and an allowance for the labour of the prisoners.

Is that calculated as free labour, or as convict labour?	[DOT]
[ Sir JOHN THOMPSON. As convict labour, 50 cents per day, because their hours are shorter and work lighter than free labour. The product is sold at a price coveiing tlie cost of the material, also interest on the expenditure for plant, allowance for deterioration, and everything that enters into the calculation of a private manufacturer.
Except the lab ur.
Not excepting the labour, but excepting free labour prices. We charge for the labour, but less than free labour prices.

A question here arises with respect to goods manufactured by convict labour, and the prices at which they are put upon the market. The government are calculating the price at convict rates, and are placing convict labour in competition with free labour. There is a large question involved; and I do not wish to enter into it now, but I want to be sure as to what is the practice of the government.

That question does not arise in this instance. The labour is computed at 50 cents per day, and it is w rth no more than that. Convict labour terminates in winter at four or five o'clock in the afternoon ; the prisoners are also later in beginning work, and the work is lighter than with free labour. In addition, I may say that we are selling the product at the same prices as the Central Prison in Toronto, the firm at Brantford, and the Consumers' Cordage Company, alth ugh I have not made an agreement with any of them. That does not look as if Sir John Thompson was regulating the price of the output. He was selling it at the same price that these competitors were seling their product at, and we forsooth are blamed because we are selling It at one or two cents a pound less than our competitors. Now, since 1880, how have we dealt with this output of binder twine ? It has been not only suggested, but it has been made a matter of positive statement that in 1S96 the output of the Kingston penitentiary was disposed of to friends of the government at a figure less

than it cost to produce it. That is charged against us. Let us look how this twine in-*dustry was dealt with previous to 1896. Let us see how those who charge us to-day with dereliction of duty acted themselves, and how many of these gentlemen protested against the action of the Conservative government.
This industry was started at Kingston in 1S94. It lirst began by installing the plant and the people of this country were made to pay $40,000 for a plant that cost the contractor in the vicinity of $18,000.
They were preparing for the elections of 1890 then.

Yes, this was previous to the elections of 1896. Not only did the people of Canada pay the figure I have mentioned, but they paid it notwithstanding that the government had called for tenders and that they had a tender for a plant of the same sort for $20,000.

I am sure that the hon. gentleman will do himself the justice to produce the evidence of the statement he has made. The Solicitor General made a similar statement last session and he expected the House to accept it without giving any proof beyond the mere statement itself.

Last session I made the statement and the hon. gentleman (Mr. Clancy) did uot contradict me, but some one on the other side suggested that perhaps my statement was incorrect. What did I answer ? I said the public accounts are there open to you.
No.

Now, Mr. Speaker, I wish to be* allowed to proceed. This system of interruption I am not going to stand just at the present time. Last session, when a similar objection was made, I suggested that this matter should be referred to the Public Accounts Committee, and I challenged the hon. gentleman to bring it before the committee. I then said that I would produce Mr. Mackey, the auditor, from Toronto, who was specially charged in connection with the suit-to which I shall have occasion to refer later on-with the examination of these accounts, and who would produce the invoices to prove the statement I made. The challenge I made then I repeat now. I say that this matter would be better dealt with before either the Public Accounts Committee or the Committee on Agriculture, where we would have an opportunity to bring witnesses and to prove the statements I have made. That is (lie place to deal with this question, and not here where we have all sorts of vague statements made by gentlemen on the other side of the House, arising from what I must at least call imperfect knowledge.
It is very kind of you to call it that.

The very same year that this twine industry was inaugurated in Kingston let us see what became of the output. Was it sold to the farmers of this country or was it sold to the combine ? I charge that in 1894, when the industry was first started, the output of that year was sold to Mr. John Connor, who at that time was the moving spirit in the binder twine combine in Canada. Mr. Connor was the man who controlled the whole of the twine industry in Canada. It was sold to him, and he entered into possession of it. He sold it as he thought best throughout the country in the interest of the combine. And then, what occurred ? At the end of the year after he had got possession of our twine he owed us for the output of 1894 something like $0,009.
You once said it was

Oh, I am going to show you in a few minutes that it was $53,000. There is no use in confuting these facts with me to-night. That was in 1894. and 1895 what happened ? The output of the penitentiary in 1895 was sold to the same Mr. John Connor, notwithstanding that in the previous year he was indebted in the sum I have mentioned. In the month of June, 1895, he had received on account of sales made of this twine which belonged to us and for which he had not paid us one farthing ; he had received $28,000. In August he got another $5,000, making it $33,000, and when the month of December of that year came around he was indebted to the government for the twine he had actually received during that season in a sum amounting to something like $40,000. And how did the government settle with him ? Notwithstanding that he had received the money and put it in his pocket in the interval. ho was settled with by taking notes from him. All that in the interests of the farmers of course. But that is not all. That goes on until the month of March, 1896. In that month it is found that there is such a thing as a Public Accounts Committee in the House of Commons. It is discovered that perhaps a question can be put with reference to the industry, and what happens ? Then Mr. Connor makes an assignment of certain claims which he has, in order to refund the government apparently the amount of money he had received during the year for the binder twine output of the Kingston penitentiary.
Then what happened? You see that up to that time we were dealing with Connor, who had sold the output of 1894. and that of 1895. and had-paid something on the output of 1894. and for 1895 had paid out .$174. on an output of $153,009. These gentlemen. who had the interest of the farmers so much at heart, could not deal with Connor any more ; that would be too barefaced ; and in 1896 what do they do? They

look around, and in place of Connor, they take Patrick Kelly, the cliief clerk of tlie Brantford industry, and constitute liim the agent for tlie sale of tlie binder twine output of that year. What does Kelly do V He makes a bargain in March. Then March goes by ; April, May, June, and July go by. Up to the change of government in July, Mr. Kelly never thought proper to carry out his contract, and the binder twine of that year was all stored at Kingston. The season went by ; the combine had accomplished their purpose ; our twine was bound up ; and the market was free to them. And yet these gentlemen talk about combines.
But that is not all. They were not content with tying up the product of 1891! in the manner I have described, and keeping it out of the market for the benefit of their friends of the combine by storing it away in the storehouse of the Kingston penitentiary. They then deliberately rise up and tell us that that twine which they had arranged to dispose of in the fashion I have described, remained on our hands to become practically valueless. We sold it at less than it cost, and they make that a crime in us. Assurance lias limits at times, but it does not appear to have many in tlie present instance. Do you realize what it means? l'ou have this binder twine stored in the spring of 1S96 ; we come in in July, 1895 ; we find a million pounds of this binder twine in the Kingston penitentiary, stored away ; the time had gone by to dispose of the output of the season. August was not the time to dispose of it. We then endeavoured to force upon Kelly the execution of his contract. He had promised to give security that he would faithfully perform his obligations under the contract, and so forth. The next thing we heard was that this clerk of the combines had disappeared and left the country. We were left in September or October with this binder twine ; and then what did we do ? Our opponents say that we sold it to friends of ours. We advertised publicly in the newspapers for tenders for tlie purchase of tlie output. We disposed of it by competition. Coll Bros, were the highest tenderers. There were three tenderers : Wood, Val-lance & Co., the Hobbs Hardware Co., and Coll Bros., who were the highest, and who got the twine. And from that time up to the first of August. 1899, the output of eacli year was disposed of in the same fashion, that is to say, by public competition, tenders being called for.
Will the hon. gentleman allow me to ask him if the output of 1898 was disposed of in that way ?
Yes.
There were public tenders invited, or was it sold to Bate & Co. without tender ?

Tenders were called for.
Mr. MONK, By circular or by public advertisement ?
By circular.
By private circular ?
By private circular.
And that is the government's conception of public advertisement ?

In 1898 circulars were issued, and the product was sold to Bate & Son. Competition took place between Bate & Son, the Hobbs Hardware Co., and Coll Bros, again. These were the only persons, besides Wood, Vallance & Co., who tendered in the previous year in answer to the public advertisement. But perhaps my hon. friend would be interested to know that when we came into power in 1896 about $50,000 was due us in connection with the output of two years previous, and it took us four years to collect the money. We had to sue for it and carry it through the courts for four years.

Will the hon. gentleman allow me to ask another question ? I would like to know if the invoices in connection with the disposal of the output of 1898 were not made out to the Hobbs Hardware Co., and if the Hobbs Hardware Co. did not pay for the output ?
I am not aware of that. I am not concerned with tlie private dealings of Bate & Son, or with how they disposed of the product.
That was not my question. I am speaking of the dealing with the department.

I do not know any further than I have stated.
Mi1. MONK. The information we have is that it was so disposed of.

It may be. I do not say that the information tlie hon. gentleman has is not correct. The output was sold and the money paid. The output was not given to an agent to collect the money, and the money carried in his pocket for twelve months, a note taken for the amount, and the money never paid.
These are in general terms the condition of this binder twine industry. Hon. gentlemen opposite took it in hand, they burdened it at its inception by paying for the installation of the plant 100 per cent more than it ought to have cost. They added to that their mismanagement of the output of 1894, 1895 and 1896. Then, after we came in, we disposed of the output of each year by

public tender until August, 1899, when we made It a condition tliat the farmers should have the right to come in and make their purchases in lots to suit themselves. This has been continued during the present year, and it is now a question to determine what shall be done next year. Notwithstanding the facilities given to the farmers to make these purchases in the manner I have described, half the output or thereabouts remained on our hands on the 1st of August last. How shall that be disposed of at the end of the year ? Shall it be disposed of at a sacrifice ; and, if the farmers will not buy the twine themselves, are we to keep it there or force it upon them in spite of themselves ?
I have stated all the facts in connection with this matter, and I repeat that the place to investigate this question, as it is one of facts and figures, is either the Public Accounts Committee, the Committee on Agriculture or a special committee. Establish the facts once and for all, and settle the position of the government with respect to their dealings with this industry, and it will be found that the only object the government have had has been that for which the industry was originally created, that is to say, to give employment to the inmates of the Kingston penitentiary, and then to dispose of the product at an honest, fair price, so that the public of this country shall not be burdened with any portion of the cost.
It seems to me, and I am sure that the farming community agree with the others in this respect, that no one class can be burdened in order that another may be benefited. It is not the desire of the farming community that we should run this at a loss to the public generally in order that they may be benefited. What they ask is that they should have an opportunity to buy the product at the cost of the raw material, plus the cost of manufacture, and something in the way of an addition to cover a reasonable remuneration in return.

I confess, Mr. Speaker, that I was a little surprised at the remarks which fell from the lips of my hon. and eloquent friend the Solicitor General, as although in one sense strictly professional, in another they were hardly such as I would expect to hear from a gentleman so quite up to date as he is. It is an old rule-so old that I thought it had become obsolete-that when the facts and the evidence are against you, be sure and oppose the attorney opposite. But, it seems to me that when a deliberative body such as this is asked to consider a simple proposition, which in no way reflects on the administration, but which simply suggests, in the interests of the people, a wiser way of conducting a certain industry, a gentleman occupying the position of the Solicitor General would have endeavoured to con-19
tribute something to assist the House in arriving at an intelligent conclusion as to' whether the system proposed was better than that hitherto followed. I venture to say that at present we might just as well discuss the events of a hundred years ago, as those of five or six years ago, even when these touch the binder twine industry.
Oh, oh.

Hon. gentlemen opposite seem amused, but, perhaps, they do not care to have the events of the last four or five years discussed. But even admitting their contention that the system now. followed is that which they inherited from their predecessors, that is no answer to the argument that the plan now proposed is an improvement on that which has been in vogue in the past.
We owe the hon. the Solicitor General thanks for telling us that from the time the present administration came into power the whole output of the penitentiary was put up to public competition. But this public competition was invited, not by means of advertisements in the newspapers, but by private circulars, and this is the hon. gentleman's idea of public competition. I would like to ask the hon. gentleman how many of these private circulars were sent out, and who were the parties that were favoured with them.
I cannot give the exact number.
Would the number be two or three or four ?
About five or six.

Here again we have an interesting piece of information and it shows what a different meaning may be attached by the hon. gentleman to certain words, compared with that ordinarily given them. I should have thought that the word ' circular' was a word, the use of which would depend a good deal upon the number that had been sent out. Supposing only one had been sent out it would be perfectly clear, it would be more properly called a letter. If it was only two that were sent out it would still be clear that it was only a letter, and that the word ' circular would be out of place as applied to it. And I venture to say that the great majority of people would think that if five or six letters were sent out privately to friends of the government, it would be hardly a fair description of the action of the government to say that this was advertising for public competition. But I rose mainly because a question was asked that I thought I could, in some part, answer. The Solicitor General asked why the farmers declined to deal with the government. A suggestion with regard to this was given by the hon. member for East York (Mr. Maclean). I venture to give



another. Last year-I cannot give the exact month, but it was several months before the general elections and, X think, in August or September-I was shown a letter received from the warden of the penitentiary by one of the farmers who had written to that official for the price of binder twine. The receiver of the letter brought it to me. It was somewhat similar in its general effect to the statement of the hon. member for Peel (Mr. Blaiu), giving different figures for different quantities of binder twine delivered on the train at Kingston. But the farmer, being dissatisfied with the figures quoted, had gone to a dealer in Belleville-a good Reformer-and had bought twine at a much lower cost than the price he was asked by the government for twine delivered on board the train at Kingston. The Solicitor General asked a perfectly fair question when he wished to know why the farmers would not deal with the government, and I think I have given a fair answer-the reason being that the government, while professing to be interested in the farmer's welfare actually proposed to charge him more for binder twine on board the cars at Kingston than the dealer would sell it for delivered at his door. A large number of people are interested in the binder twine industry and in what becomes of the product of the government factory at Kingston ; and the hon. gentleman who brought this question before the House felt, as I Judge from the line of his remarks in which he referred to the disposal of the binder twine from 1896 down to this date, that the people who were interested were not fairly treated. Ascertaining from such facts as those brought before us by the hon. member for South Brant that in the sale of binder twine there were enormous profits, he naturally said that if private binder twine works are making-large profits, and if the government, composed of men of great ability, carries on a similar industry, there must naturally be large profits for that industry ; and the question naturally arises where those profits go. No one can look at the prices paid by friends of the government-and no one can deny that those who were fortunate enough to obtain this binder twine were friends of the government-and see also the prices at which the material was sold to the people and fail to see that not only was a profit made but that it went in a direction in which it should not go. The simple issue before the House is. whether the profits that have been made will continue to go to those who have handled the binder twine for the last four or five years, or to the farmers. The hon. member for Peel objects to the present plan, and the appeals to the House to adopt a better way, one by which the profits will go to the farmer rather than to the friends of the government. I would have thought that the hon. member for South Brant would have given some arguments to show that the course Mr. NORTHRUP.
adopted by the government was that best calculated to promote the interest of the majority of the people or else would have adopted the course suggested by the hon. member for Peel. But, if this debate has had no other advantages it has had two. it has had the advantage of teaching us the meaning attached to certain words by the Solicitor General, who, no doubt, speaks for the government ; and it has given us the pleasure of hearing a speech from the member for South Brant as thoroughly protectionist as any ever delivered on this side of the House. I wonder if the hon. gentleman (Mr. Heyd) also attached a different meaning to the words he used from those that we attach to them and is prepared to call himself, in certain quarters, a protectionist, meaning thereby, protection to that in which he is interested and free trade for the rest of the world. I hope that the government will consider the proposition made by the hon. member for Peel. It is possible it may not be the best means of dealing with the question. I am not certain that a better plan may not be suggested ; but I shall support it because it is incomparably superior to the course followed by the government for the last four years, and I consider it to be my duty on this floor to support the best measure proposed, even though it may not be in every respect perfect.

I have received a memorandum which enables me to give the information with reference to tenders asked for by the hon. gentleman (Mr. Northrup). Tenders were advertised for in all the years except 1898, and in that year tenders were called for by circular. Then the leading wholesale dealers, without respect to politics, had circulars sent to them on the recommendation of the inspector, Mr. Stewart, who was instructed to send them to all such. At least one dozen were sent to various parts of the country in 1898.

I am glad the hon. Solicitor General made that statement before I spoke, because the hon. member for East Hastings (Mr. Northrup) will now see that there is no need for a new dictionary. If for two years there was advertisement in the public press, and if, in the third year, knowing just the parties who took advantage of the opportunity offered. circulars were sent out to them under the direction of a well-known Conservative at the head of the business, a gentleman appointed by hon. gentlemen opposite, I think the government have done everything they ought to be called upon to do. There is one thing that the hon. member who has made this resolution should do. In fairness he should stand up now and offer to do it. He should offer that if the farmers do not take all the binder twine manufactured at Kingston he will purchase the bal-

ance. He wants the government to carry on this business. He should desire the government not to lose in doing so. If, in response to the government's advertisements all the parties who might have done so, did not send in tenders for the product of the factory at Kingston, it may have been for one of two reasons.
They did not get a chance.

Does the hon. gentleman (Mr. Monk) think it fair, when advertisements were inserted in the newspapers for two successive years calling upon people to tender and only certain people did tender, to say, that, because in the third year, all the parties who did tender were asked to tender again, they did not have a chance ?

I suppose the hon. gentleman (Mr. Fraser) wishes me to answer his question, and I shall do so. I do not think it is fair to sell 1,429,035 pounds of binder twine at $66,883.27 to parties who can sell it agaiii for $199,750.72, making a profit of $133,167.15.

Is that from the Public Accounts ? Now, if the hon. gentleman thinks that that is smart, I venture to say this House does not think so. If he reads from an article got up specially in the interests of his own party, he will not find that a sufficient answer. What was the hon. gentleman reading from ?
Do you deny the figures ?

I do deny them. I rather think that the Tycoon of the opposition leadership would have appeared to better advantage if he did not attempt to answer in that way. The dual capacity in which the party finds its leadership will not be strengthened by efforts of that kind. I was about to say that, for myself, I think the late government entered into this business on purpose to fool the farmers ; I have no more doubt of that than I have that I am talking. For the last ten or twelve years I have heard men in this parliament who wanted to get the farmers' vote, talking about binder twine It has been a continual subject of discussion.
On your side, too.

I do not deny that. But with the exposure made by the Solicitor General, and the challenges made to hon. gentlemen opposite to call for a committee and examine witnesses under oath, I do not think we will have as much trouble in the future in relation to this question. For myself, I think the government should never have entered into the business. We have paid twice as much for the machinery as it ought to cost. I do not believe it is the business of the government to enter into the manufacture of binder twine at Kingston, any more than it would he to enter into any other manufacturing business. There is plenty of other work the 19}
convicts could do. I think, now that the duty is off binder twine, that the case is quite clear. What would any business man do to-day ? Let the government, now that the duty has been taken off, put up at competition the manufactured product, and every bit of raw material that they have on hand, together with this machinery that has cost twice as much as it should cost, and let them sell it all and go out of the business. At least, by that means we would avoid all the trouble of these discussions. Then, if binder twine is an absolute necessity to the existence of the farmers, they could get it without duty from the outside, in case it could not be manufactured within this country. Here is a way in which the whole problem could be clearly solved. The hon. member for East York (Mf< Maclean) has a panacea for everything that comes up, namely, to take the railways over, and then all difficulties would be solved. But I think he will admit that this Kingston penitentiary difficulty would not be solved except by the government going out of the business altogether. I may say that this is a question that does not affect us so much in Nova Scotia as it appears to affect the people of Ontario. But if, as has been clearly shown, the government have sold an article at the lowest price, if these people who are in the same business are to be believed, and I would trust them to tell the facts more than I would that single individual farmer that the hon. member for Hastings has told us about, if the evidence of the Solicitor General is to be taken, the government have sold the twine at a less price than it was sold elsewhere; and having taken the duty off binder twine, I think they have done all that they should do. Now, I would suggest to them that they should clear the decks of this question altogether, sell out everything ; and that would prevent a number of hon. gentlemen from talking for ever about this question of binder twine. It would give an opportunity to the manufacturers of the country to compete with each other in manufacturing a good article for the farmers, that they could get at the lowest price. I offer the suggestion in all modesty, and I trust it will be accepted ; and I have no doubt hon. gentlemen opposite will join with me in endeavouring to relieve this wicked government, as they consider it to be, from the necessity of dealing in binder twine to the disadvantage of the farmers.

I have listened with a good deal of Interest to the discussion that has been in progress to-night. I may say that this is a question of considerable interest to the farmers in North Middlesex, the riding which I have the honour to represent. I may say also that I am a farmer, and I never was more proud of being so than I have been tonight, when I heard the hon. member for Halifax (Mr. Roche), getting up and calling

himself a farmer, whom I am informed on good authority is one of those wealthy coal merchants down in Nova Scotia. This binder twine question is one of considerable importance to the agricultural community. The hon. gentleman who has just spoken (Mr. Fraser) proposes that the government should go out of the business altogether. That hon. gentleman, and some others who have spoken on that side of the House, have had a good deal to say, but they have all failed to suggest any way by which the business could be carried on on business lines. The hon. member for Guysborough started out to draw comparisons. I do not think that is the proper course to pursue on this question. It would be just about as fair to argue that, because a man has had his hat stolen at some time, another man would be justified in going and taking his boots. The hon. gentleman states that it costs 7i cents to produce this twine. I have not heard any argument put forth that would show this House that the government ever offered this twine at a time when it was possible for the farmers to obtain it, at any such figure, or at any figure that would be a fail-price, as their advertised price to farmers was 11 cents to 14 cents per pound. Some wild suggestions have been made from the other side of the House, but there has been no proof that binder twine had ever been offered to the farmers, as I said before, at less than 14 cents for best quality.
Now, it seems to me this is a state of affairs which should not exist. The motion before the House, I approve of in the main, though I do not believe exactly in that one-cent proposition. I think it possible that some way could be devised by which this twine could be sold to the farmers at a less price than nearly double what it costs to produce, i was thinking, when listening to some hon. gentlemen opposite that if they had been in my riding previous to the 7th of November last, they would have had some difficulty, notwithstanding the talent they exhibited here to-night, in convincing the farmers that they have been properly dealt with in this matter. The result of the election in my riding shows that the policy of the government in reference to this binder twine question as well as other matters, had been distasteful to the farmers. Ontario has spoken out against the government on this matter, and I believe, amongst all the bad things that have been done by the government, no action that has been taken has promoted the interests of the opposition more in that province than the action of the government upon this very question. It was not on account of the unpopularity of our late member, or on account of my own popularity that the campaign in my constituency resulted as it did, but it was the action of the government on this and other questions that placed me in this House. I do not wish to detain the House or to enter upon Mr. SHERRITT.
a lengthy discussion of the matter, but my idea is that this binder twine was offered at a time when the farmers could not avail themselves of the offer. The offer was made so much in advance of the time that they actually needed it, the time that many farmers were not prepared to purchase it. I think if the government desired to assist the farmers they would leave the offer open until the 1st of July. That would give them ample time, and if they then found that orders were not coming in from the farmers they would have an opportunity of sending men out and in some way disposing of the twine throughout the country. I believe the matter has been very badly handled in the past. When the hon. member for West Elgin (Mr. Robinson) referred to the question the other day he stated that he was an independent man. We should show, on both sides of the House, that we are all independent men. It does seem to me that we should show our independence on these lines, notwithstanding the fact that we may be sitting on one side of the House or the other. I know what I am speaking about when I say that if any hon. gentlemen, sitting on the other side of the House, representing a farming community, who-votes against this motion will be giving a vote contrary to his own opinion, and which, apart from political considerations, he would not give.

Mr. Speaker, this question of binder twine is a most important one to the agricultural constituencies of this country. I am very sorry that the motion and the mover of the motion have not been paid a greater compliment by the hon. members who have spoken, supposedly to the motion, but really not to it at all. I think there has seldom been a motion presented to this House which has been less discussed than this motion now before us. We have heard a rehash of certain pages of the Conservative literature of the last election, which most of us have all heard for hour after hour, given with the utmost gravity and good faith, as if it were something original and something that no one had ever heard before. I did not suppose, when I read that literature first, or when I heard it delivered from platform after platform during the election, that the men who used it believed it. I did not suppose that they were so lacking in ordinary knowledge and common sense, but now I am bound to believe that they talked it so long that they not only have come to believe it themselves, but they think they can make other people believe it by continuing to talk it. What is the purpose of all this talk about binder twine ? What was the [DOT] purpose of the literature that was circulated through the country, and what was the purpose of the campaign that was made in regard to binder twine in the late election ? I am at

a loss to understand what the purpose is of the greater part of this debate, but the purpose of the attack upon the policy of the government in regard to binder twine during the election was to blind the eyes of the farming community if possible to the wise action of the government in abolishing the duty on binder twine, and making that product, at any rate, free to the farmers as far as the tariff was concerned. Whatever pledge in regard to the reduction of the tariff the government may have failed in, it did not fail on the article of binder twine. Therefore, as binder twine is an article of the highest importance to that part of the community which forms the largest part of the electorate, it was necessary to deceive, if possible, the farmers as to the value of the action of the government to them. It was for that reason and that alone that the campaign of misrepresentation, of slander and falsehood, which has seldom or never been equalled in any country, was carried on on the basis of binder twine during the late election, and the fact that in that part of the country where binder twine is more important than in any other, the government's policy was sustained by a vote of four to nothing, is a sufficient answer to it. The government abolished the duty upon binder twine ; they fulfilled to the utmost limit their pledge in regard to the tariff on that article, they benefited the farmers by doing so, and then the charge was made that they had used the output of the Kingston penitentiary to unduly increase the price of the article to the farmers. A case was built up in regard to the misuse of the binder twine of the penitentiary which the bon. gentleman (Mr. Sherritt), who preceded me in this debate, declared was the cause of his return to this House and the defeat of his opponent. So successful were the opposition in that campaign of misrepresentation that they made a majority of the electors of North Middlesex believe that the government, by manipulating one-tenth of the binder twine used in this country, bad increased the price by 100 per cent. I will admit that you can manipulate the output of the Kingston penitentiary so as to affect the price of binder twine to a proportionate degree, but that was not the contention that was put up. The contention was exactly what I say, that the government had so manipulated the output of the Kingston penitentiary, being one-tenth of the total consumption of the bidder twine of this country, that they had doubled the price of twine to the farmers, an utterly preposterous proposition. The idea has been held out to the farmers that they depended on the output of the Kingston penitentiary for their binder twine. My opponent said to the farmers in one section of the country, where 1 had the pleasure of meeting him : You do not use American binder twine: ' It
makes no difference to you that the duty has been taken off twine. As long as the government hold up the price of twine manufactured at the Kingston penitentiary, so long will you have to pay that price. That is what interests you.' I made inquiries and I found that there never had been a pound of Kingston penitentiary twine sold in that part of the country. The point I want to make is this : That the idea has been attempted to be implanted in the minds of the people of this country that something has been done, or attempted to be done with the twine output of the Kingston penitentiary that never was done or attempted to be done by this government or by the late government, and that never could be done by any government. However that is in regard to the last election and having fought through that campaign. Having heard the slanders that were hurled against the policy of the government; it is certainly a pleasure for me now to come to this House and find a member of the Conservative party coming forward with a resolution endorsing the policy of the government in regard to binder twine. That disposes effectually of all the slanders uttered during that campaign and puts them exactly where they belong. We need not consider them any more. As the Solicitor General said : The government did during the past year offer the twine direct to the farmers at a fixed price. The charge was that the government had sold the twine to a combine, whereas as a matter of fact they had offered the twine to the farmers and part of it they were unsuccessful in selling to any one. The motion of the hon. gentleman (Mr. Blain) endorses the principle pursued by the government last year. I do not know that it is a principle of universal application. I do not know .just how well it will work out in practice. It may be that sometime we shall attempt to sell twine direct to the farmers on the basis of the cost of the raw material. In the meantime the raw material may go down in price and the farmer can buy his twine cheaper from the other manufacturers. Another feature is that if the raw material maintains its price or if it increases in price, it is possible for the government to make a very considerable difference between the price of the penitentiary twine and the market price of twine, and then I am afraid we will have our friends opposite charging that the output of the Kingston penitentiary is being used as a bribe to the farmers of the country, by giving a preference to the friends of the government on this low priced twine. I am perfectly satisfied that so long as the present government is in power there is no danger of that taking place, but I am not at all satisfied that should the opposition come to power they will not carry out the traditions of their Conservative predecessors. These features

are worthy of consideration, hut they are questions of the future. The question of the present is, that for some reason or other, whether on account of the combine or whether it is an accident of the market ; the binder twine of this country has been sold at abnormally high prices during the past year or two. We do know that the government of Canada controls the output of the Kingston penitentiary, and I am entirely in accord with the hon. gentleman's motion -which I distinguish entirely from his remarks-that at the present time it is the duty of the government to use the output of the Kingston penitentiary to check, so far as that output can, any possible combine whereby the price of binder twine is increased to the farmers. That being the case X would have been very glad to accept the motion, but it contains a feature which is a very great weakness and which is not necessary to its principle. That is that in the case of the farmers not purchasing the total output (which occurred this year) no provision is made as to what is to be done with the residue. Is it to be carried over to another year when possibly the price of the raw material having gone down it will be unsaleable except at a loss. The suggestion made by the hon. member for North Middlesex (Mr. Sherritt) was that the twine should be offered to the farmers up to a certain date, and that after that date It should be offered for sale to the highest bidder. That is a fair proposition and I will take the liberty of moving an amendment along that line, I do not exactly agree however that the government should be entitled to a cent a pound over the cost of manufacture. The government having control of the penitentiary and having to find work for the convicts, it is right that they should sell that twine at its fair cost. But then comes the question of the cost of twine manufactured by prison labour, and I do not wish to conflict with our friends in the House who are here in the interests of labour, and who have a very natural deep rooted objection against the competition of prison labour. I would like to have their support for any motion I put before the House, because I believe that the true interests of the labouring men of Canada are exactly the same as the interests of the farmers. I propose to amend the motion by striking out the cent a pound extra over cost, and placing the cost as if the twine were produced by free labour. My amendment is this :
That so long as the government continues to manufacture twine, the same shall be offered for sale directly to farmers up to July the 1st of each year at cost of material and manufacture, calculating wages on the basis of fair wages for free labour ; and that the twine unsold and on hand on July 1st of each year be sold by tender to the highest bidder, after advertisement.
That is entirely in line with the policy pursued by the government during the past Mr. OLIVER.
year, except that ?t carries it a little further and makes it more definite. It is also in line with the motion of the hon. member for Peel (Mr. Blain). As the representative of an agricultural constituency, I would ask the members representing agricultural constituencies in this House to vote for that amendment without respect to politics or arguments in respect to past transactions either by one government or the other.

Mr. Speaker, I am sure the tone of the hon. gentleman's speech was such that he might ask hon. gentlemen on both sides of the House to vote for the proposal that he has made; for those who followed him somewhat closely could see that he spoke entirely from a non-partisan standpoint. The hon. gentleman was very moderate, I fancy he thought himself. He commenced his speech by declaring that the whole country were fools, that no man of ordinary intelligence could have believed a single word contained in certain campaign literatures which was circulated in the country. I desire to remind that hon. gentleman that he sat in this House, and his leader sat in this House when those statements were made here, and that up to this moment not an hon. gentleman has challenged one of those statements.

 I do not think the hon. gentleman intended to reflect upon his leaders, but he has not shown that knowledge of the question one would expect from a gentleman who assumed such a lofty tone as he assumed a few moments ago. If he will take his pencil, and go to his room, and spend a few hours there, he will never again make such an exhibition in this House as he has made this evening. I venture to repeat the statements which were made here on former occasions, and made in what the hon. gentleman rather opprobriously called campaign literature, and which have remained to this moment uncontradicted.
What is the position of the Solictor General to-night ? He set forth as a proper answer to the charges that the machinery at the Kingston penitentiary had been purchased at an exorbitant price; but he sat down without giving a single particle of evidence in support of that bald statement. He simply said that one Mr. Munro would be able to present the evidence at the Public Accounts Committee. Well, the Solicitor General made the statement, and it devolves upon him to bring the matter before the Public Accounts Committee and there present the evidence to prove it. It does not devolve upon this side of the House to do that. The first thing the hon. gentleman said was that in August, 1809, the twine had been sold to the farmers of this country on precisely the terms proposed by the motion of the hon. member for Peel (Mr. Blain). Now, I have here an advertisement that appeared during last session in the public press. It is dated the 26th of February,

and I believe this House met last year on tlie 1st of February. An advertisement appeared in the public press some time before that; but, public attention was called to it during the session, and the hon. gentleman saw fit to amend the notice with regard to the sale of twine; and what does it say ?
Orders from farmers in pursuance of the advertisement dated January 22nd will be received and filed until the 20th of March, instead of the 1st of March, as stipulated in the former advertisement.
Now, what were the stipulations sent out to the farmers ? Let it be remembered that this twine with one cent added for manufacture was sold at 7'51 cents a pound. What is the farmer asked to pay ? In lots of fifty tons and upwards-for manila 124. cents, for mixed 94 cents, and for New Zealand 84 cents. No farmers are likely to buy twine in fifty ton lots, as the hon. gentleman knew perfectly well, and it was idle to put such a notice before them. The price to the farmers in carload lots, which is less than fifty tons, is for manila 13 cents, for mixed 10 cents, and for New Zealand 9 cents. In lots of one ton up to a carload, the price was-for manila 134 cents, for mixed 104 cents, and for New Zealand 94 cents. For smaller quantities, such quantities as my hon. friend knows the farmers will purchase, what was the price to them ? Bearing in mind that the cost price of this twine, including manufacture, was an average of 7-51, what was the great inducement offered to the farmers ? Why, in lots of less than one ton, they were paying for manila 14 cents, mixed 11 cents, and New Zealand 10 cents. After that advertisement had appeared on the 25th February of last session, this is what the hon. gentleman gave out, and yet he does not hesitate to rise in his place and declare that the twine from 1899, up to the present was sold at a slight advance on the cost of producing.
I would like to ask the hon. gentleman if he is prepared to withdraw the statements made in this House last session, of which I gave him a sample a moment ago? I do not say that he intended to mislead the House, but he made statements by which the House was misled.
Another statement which the hon. gentleman made was that if the twine were held over it would be a loss. In other words, that if the twine were held over more than a year it would have to be sold at a loss.
Yes.

I shall not ask this House to rely entirely on any statement I make in this matter, but we had an investigation, and had witnesses examined. Mr. Hughes was examined, and the hon. gentleman tried to make it appear that twine would be deteriorated by being held over, but Mr. Hughes stated that being held over one year would not matter, but it would not
do to hold it over two years, so that there is nothing in the hon. gentleman's plea that he was justified in forcing a sale because it would not do to hold over the twine.
I am instructed by the warden of the penitentiary to that effect.

The warden is a man new to the office, and his opinion cannot be taken against that of Mr. Hughes, who has had many years experience in the business.	_
Then the hon. gentleman said : Well, the farmers will not deal with us. I think 1 gave the reasons a moment ago. The farmers were led to believe by the hon. gentleman's friends that they would get the twine at a price slightly above cost. But they had to pay very exorbitant prices. My hon. friend replied that some dealers in twine had said : You are selling twine much less than the price manufacturers ought to get. But naturally the very men who wished to put up the price could not be expected to say anything else.
The hon. gentleman made some statement with regard to Mr. Connor to which I desire to call particular attention. One was that Sir. Connor had sold twine in 1894 at excessive prices.
He bought it from the department and retailed it to the public. I never was aware of the prices at which he sold it, and it did not concern us.
Yet the hon. gentleman stated that Connor was in the combine, and was selling at combine prices.

Yes. In 1894 he purchased the output outright and disposed of it in the market himself. In 1895, he sold it as agent of the government, and received 10 per cent commission on the sales, but simply forgot to pay for it. That is all.
That is what Connor has to say on that subject when brought before the Public Accounts Committee.
I do not care what he says, I have the contract.
That is what he says with regard to the prices at which he sold it.

The statement I made was that Mr. Connor was the chief factor in the combine that existed at that time, which combine had closed up all the factories in Canada except the ones at Brantford and at Montreal, and that, in that capacity, he secured the agency for the sale of the government twine at a commission of 10 per cent.

Connor swears that he was under special instructions in 1895. The hon. member for South Leeds (Mr. Taylor) asked him : ' What did you sell the twine at in 1895 ?' And Connor replied :	' The
average price for mixed was 5J cents.' The member for Leeds then asked him :	' The
government gave you a limit to sell at ?' And Connor replied :	' Yes, from time to
time I was to advise with the warden and be governed by him.' Now the hob. gentleman has made the charge, first, that Connor in 1894 secured the binder twine and fleeced the people.

Yes.
Mr, CLANCY. Has the hon. gentleman offered a tittle of evidence to prove that V He has utterly failed to do so. We come to 1895, and we have the fact that Connor, who sold the twine for the government, was under special instructions, and sold the twine at 51 cents.
Then the hon. gentleman said that in 1896 Mr. Kelly had the contract, and the government tried to get him to give security. But if the hon. gentleman has told the whole story, he would have been more frank. What was it ? It was that the late government exacted that Kelly should give security for the twine, and Kelly having failed to give security, they would not give him the twine. I ask my hon. friend if he did not find that state of things when he came into office. Mr. Kelly was unable to furnish the secruity, and the result was that the twine was held over and not sold that season. But, did the hon. gentleman wait till next season ? No, he sold the twine in September of that year, after he had been only a few months in office to Coll Bros.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: Connor.

Connor was acting for Coll Bros. Are they twine dealers ? No, they are soap manufacturers in St. John. Yet the hon. gentleman made the sale on the plea that the twine would deteriorate if left over, although we have the evidence of an expert that it was without a tittle of foundation. And who is this man Connor ? Has not the hon. gentleman had dealings witli him during last year ? Did he not sell Mr. Connor a good deal of the twine of 1900 ? And why did he do that if Mr. Connor is not in favour with the government ? I take it that he is the same man who went to the county of Victoria, N.B., and helped to buy out the opposition candidate. Mr. Connor is a friend of the hon. gentleman opposite, though the hon. gentleman assumes to blame him here tonight. Mr. Connor gave evidence in the presence of the hon. gentleman himself and swore that, from 1890 to 189S, three successive years there was collusion in regard to the binder twine, and that the ministers of the Crown were aware of it-they knew that

there was a combine. The hon. gentleman asked how the price could be affected by the small quantity of twine produced in the Kingston penitentiary. The hon. gentleman has political friends in Toronto who were clamouring as lustily as hon. gentlemen opposite did for years to have factories started in the Kingston penitentiary and the Central prison for the purpose of compelling manufacturers to accept fair prices. I will call one of the most respectable witnesses on this point, the Minister of Customs (Hon. Mr. Paterson), who is always moderate and thoughtful in his statements. If hon. gentlemen will turn to ' Hansard ' of 1893, page 3433, they will find that, in the course of a discussion on the desirability of establishing a binder twine factory in Kingston, the hon. Minister of Customs says :
The government is taking this action with a view to employ prison labour and at the same time keep the manufacturers at Halifax from obtaining too high a price for their product.
Then, we have Mr. Dryden, the Minister of Agriculture of Ontario. In a speech made on January 24, 1894, at Columbus, in his own riding, he said :
Another reason why this industry was established was that the farmers laboured under the burden of a monopoly, and it was thought desirable that the product of the prisoners' labour would be used in the interest of the farmer. He showed how the farmers had paid monopolists for the ropes, wrappings, &c., at the twine price, but in future

This is a pledge to the people

-they would have a guarantee that the prison twine would be all right in quality and weight. He intended to use his influence in future to supply the farmers with the twine at first cost. Business must of necessity be done on a cash basis. But as a good many farmers cannot pay cash, some means will have to be devised to give them the benefit of this industry.
He is not only to sell it at cost but he is going to trust the purchasers. And how did it turn out ? Precisely as the professions of the hon. gentlemen opposite tprned out who, for years, clamoured to have this industry established but who, the moment they came into power was shown by sworn evidence, while knowing there was collusion, allowed the combine to be formed. And how was it formed ? By Mr. Connor and the Coll Bros, going up to Toronto, purchasing the twine there and getting the two years' output of the Kingston penitentiary-making a large quantity of twine-and then combining with the American Cordage Company. And who are the agents of that company ? Why, Hobbs Bros, of London. So that all that was necessary was to call in Hobbs Bros, and the combine was formed. And the result was that the twine that was purchased from the government at 4 cents was sold to the farmers at 10, 12 and 14 cents. It is well enough for hon. gentlemen opposite to say that there was no combine ; but I would like any hon. gentleman who is disposed to

look at the question fairly to account for the great disparity between the prices at which the twine was sold by the government from year to year and the price at which it was sold to the consumer. No attempt has ever been made to do that.
I will not pursue this subject any further.
1 have to say to the Solicitor General that he is bound, after the statement he has made this evening, to call his auditor, Mr. Munro, and to make his case good. As for Mr. Connor, that gentleman is a friend of his own, and we have no concern with him. As regards the motion in amendment, I do not think it is in order. It simply reaffirms what is affirmed in the original motion, it does not substantially contain new matter, as it must do in order to be an amendment. It simply repeats, by the variation of dates, the substance of the motion of my hon. friend. I consider it to be entirely harmless, but not in order. I wish to point out to hon. gentlemen that if they accept that motion they bind themselves by the dates; and I ask the First Minister if he is prepared to bind himself in the sense of that amendment as to the dates. I desire to say to the Solicitor General that I do not think he was quite fair in his mode of dealing with this question to-night. There was really no need for the heat he displayed in the discussion. In the iirst place lie utterly failed in making a single statement good. His statement with regard to the cost of the machinery may be true, I do not offer any opinion upon it, I have no information on the subject; but if it be true, it does not affect the case in the slightest, it has nothing to do with the sale of twine. Now there is twine enough manufactured in the Central prison and in the Kingston penitentiary, if the hon. gentlemen can control their friends there, they too affect materially the price of binder twine In Canada. It has been stated here tonight that the consumption of twine is something like sixteen million pounds, and that a considerable share of it is manufactured in those two institutions, and the others will be governed to some extent by the price at which this is sold. I know there is always a difficulty in dealing with so many persons in a business of this kind, I grant it is not an easy thing for the government to sell twine in a satisfactory manner. But, I agree with the hon. gentleman's motion that if we are going to employ prison labour in Canada it ought to be employed for the benefit of the people of Canada. The object of the motion is to secure that the twine should be sold in the best possible way to the farmer, and in order to do that hon. gentlemen will hardly pursue the course of asking as high as 12 and 14 cents a pound for twine when it is sold to dealers at an average of -S7.51 per hundred.

I wish to say to the House that I see very little
difference between the amendment proposed by the hon. member for Alberta (Mr. Oliver) and the resolution I submitted to the House a few days ago. I have to say that I am willing to accept the motion in amendment because I see very little difference between that and my own. Now, I wish to say a word as to the motive I had in introducing this resolution; and to show that I had no political motive, and had no desire to catch any special vote in this country, I want to read the words of the Prime Minister at the close of the debate the other day :
The government certainly has no right to complain of the manner in which my hon. friend (Mr. Blain) has introduced this motion.
I think that is good proof from the leader of the government that what I said upon the question is not open to the criticism that has been made by some hon. gentlemen opposite. I want also to draw attention to the fact that no farmer, no gentleman engaed in agricultural pursuits speaking from the other side of the House, has said one word against my motion. The first gentleman who spoke upon the question was the hon. member for Brant (Mr. Heyd), but he represents a constituency that contains a binder twine manufactory. Then the hon. member for Halifax (Mr. Roche) ventured to state that the leader of the opposition received a very large vote from the binder twine manufactory in the county of Halifax. I thought we had a secret vote in this country. How can any man say how people voted in that county on the 7tli of November ? Then we have the hon. member for Kent (Mr. Stephens) speaking in defence of the twine industry in this country, but, I believe he is a large seller of binder twine himself, and, therefore, he wants a little protection upon that point, not having the interest of the farmer in view at all. Then we had the hon. member for Guysborougli (Mr. Fraser), who is a lawyer, I believe, and not a farmer, who spoke in defence of the government. Therefore, the House will see that no gentleman representing the agricultural interests of the I country attempted to say anything against ; the motion that I had the honour to introduce. Then, I think I ought to get some credit from the House, because my motion has brought into the House, the hon. Solicitor General, who is not often in his place. I was only sorry that he was not in better temper after being away so long.
In my resolution I ask that two things should be done; first, that these middlemen should disappear. If the terms of the amendment of the member for Alberta be adopted by this House, then Coll Bros, will be no more in the transaction, because they are not farmers. They bought the twine in 1896. In 1897, the Hobbs Co. bought it. and they will be no more in the business because they are uot farmers. The twine was sold to H. N. Bate & Sons in 1898, and as they are grocers they will uot come in

under the new deal. Therefore, I willingly accept the terms of the amendment, because all these middlemen, who the farmers claim have been making large profits out of the binder twine industry, will disappear, and that is what I want. There is one other point, and that is as to what the profits should be. My motion says that the profits should be one cent; the amendment says that the profit should be based upon a calculation of paid labour in this country. I am not quite sure what difference there would be in the calculation, but I am sure there could not be much. Therefore, upon that point I am willing to accept the amendment of the member for Alberta. I am glad to know that hon. gentlemen opposite, including the Solicitor General, 1 presume, are willing that there should be a change. The member for South Brant (Mr. Heyd) said that the transaction was altogether unsatisfactory to himself as a supporter of the government; so of course I should have his support. I am delighted to see that the government are willing to change their plan, and that they are now willing to adopt the terms of the resolution; therefore, I presume It will pass unanimously.
the legitimate industries of the country, it is only fair and reasonable and right, under conditions of free trade, there being no duty, that we should not put prison labour in competition with free labour, and that while we are competing with outside factories, whether it is the combine in Halifax, which elects the hon. leader of the opposition (Mr. Borden, Halifax)-
Oh, oh.

What is wrong ? I speak that which I know. I say that if it were not for the combine votes, I doubt if the hon. gentleman would have a seat in this House, and then we would only have three leaders on that side of the House instead of four, as at the present time. I say that when we have to compete with the legitimate industries of the country, even though you may call them combines, it is not fair in competing to place prison labour against free labour, and therefore the hon. member for Alberta (Mr. Oliver) says that in any calculation that can be made in respect to labour, that calculation must be on the basis of free labour, and not prison labour.

As we are about to vote upon these propositions we had better have it clearly understood what they are. When the hon. gentleman says the two propositions are the same, he is certainly labouring under a misapprehension. There are two radical differences between the two motions. First, in relation to the cost ,ol* producing the binder twine. So far as that is an element in the motion of the member for Peel (Mr. Blain), he proposes that no regard should be had to the distinction between prison labour and free labour. We propose, or the member for Alberta proposes-
WTlio are we ?
I am going to vote for it.
Then it is a put up job.

Then it is a very good job, because it is common sense, and the hon. gentleman is going to vote for it too, and will set a very good example, because sometimes he votes for propositions which are not sensible. So far as the cost of labour is concerned, the hon. mover of this motion makes no distinction between free labour and prison labour.
We are willing to do so.
I am glad the hon. gentleman has come to that. I hope he will continue to accept useful suggestions from this side of the House.
How long is it since the hon. gentleman has come to these views ?
What are the views that the hon. gentleman refers to ?
How long is it since the hon. gentleman has entertained the view that the labour employed in the Kingston penitentiary in the manufacture of binder twine should be equal to that of free labour ?

I think my hon. friend will find that has always been held. His complaint is that we have been charging too much, and that clearly shows that we have net been putting it on a basis of prison labour, which would make the price less. The hon. member for Peel (Mr. Blain) says that we have been Charging too much for prison-made twine.
You entered into a combine.
A cent a pound.

My hon. friend from Peel says that he has no conception whether that represents the cost of labour at all. He says that he has made no calculation upon that basis. Inasmuch as it is unavoidable from our operations at the Kingston penitentiary binder twine factory that we must enter into competition with
lion, gentlemen talk of combines ; why, they flourished on combines for eighteen years.
And you are following that up.
I want to call the attention of the hon. member for Peel (Mr. Blain), having mentioned this

one important difference, to the other material difference between his proposition and that of the hon. member for Alberta (Mr. Oliver). The hon. member for Peel proposes that we shall sell this binder twine to the farmers at a certain price, regardless of whether the farmer is willing to buy it from us or not, and he then says distinctly that even if the farmer does not buy it you shall not be at liberty to sell it in any other way, and therefore you can keep it and let it rot if you like. That does not strike us as a very reasonable proposition. The hon. member for Alberta says that you shall offer this to the farmers at a fair price up to a certain date, and if the farmers take it at that price, well and good, but if the farmers do not take it at that price, then instead of allowing it to rot, as it would under the proposal of the hon. member for Peel, you shall advertise in the public press for tenders, and sell the balance of it in the open market at the best price.
May I ask the hon. gentleman what they are going to do with the amount of binder twine now in the Kingston penitentiary ? Are they going to allow that to rot ?

There is one thing certain ; if it rots now it does not rot through any lack of effort on the part of the government to sell it, but the hon. member for Peel is proposing a scheme, which, no matter how many buyers we might find, would not permit us to sell the surplus at all.

Mr. Speaker, when I asked the hon. Minister of Finance (Mr. Fielding) the question, how long it is since he entertained these views, I was surprised that the hon. gentleman did not answer. I have always found him courteous and all that sort of thing. Since hon. gentlemen have controlled the affairs of this country, I do not know any case where they have been prevented from selling binder twine at the actual cost, that is to say, charging what would be equal to free labour in the manufacture of twine in other factories. Therefore, the hon. gentleman had it right in his own hands if he entertained these views, ever since he came into power. In respect to the motion moved by the hon. member for Alberta (Mr. Oliver), it strikes me that the hon. gentleman must have had this motion placed in his hands, because he possesses the faculty of speaking one way and moving a resolution in an entirely different direction. The hon. gentleman's speech was not the speech of an independent man. I doubt very much, whether, in his election in Alberta, the issue was really on the question of binder twine. I had the opportunity of passing through that hon. gentleman's district, and it struck me that he represented a grazing country. I read the papers pretty
closely during the last campaign, and it occurred to me that the question of scrip had more effect in his election than the question of binder twine. I remember crossing the river at Edmonton, in his constituency, and there was no bridge at the time of my crossing. It strikes me that this was another very important issue in his constituency. So, I say, that instead of charging the electors of other portions of the Dominion with being ignorant on this question and not capable of arriving at a proper conclusion as to whether binder twine was properly dealt with by his government or not, he should have been more frank in his statements, and they should have been more in keeping with the actions of an independent member. Therefore, for that reason, while I support the amendment proposed by the hon. gentleman, I entirely differ from the remarks he made in moving his resolution.
0. DAVIS (Saskatchewan). Mr. Speaker
Oh, oh.

If hon. gentlemen will possess their souls in patience, I can assure them that I am not going to take up the time of the House. I may just say that the hon. gentleman (Mr. Blain) who moved the original motion, complained that there were no hon. gentlemen on this side of the House representing agricultural constituencies who had taken any exception to the motion he had moved.
That is not what he said.

That is how I understood the hon. gentleman. However, I am not going to take up very much time. I am sure the farmers of the North-west Territories will be very much pleased to learn that they have the sympathy of hon. gentlemen on the opposition side of the House who sympathize so much with the farmers of the North-west Territories and other parts of the Dominion.
